Sample Optimality and All-for-all Strategies in Personalized Federated and Collaborative Learning


Mathieu Even1, Laurent MassouliÃ©1,2 and Kevin Scaman1


1Inria - DÃ©partement dâ€™informatique de lâ€™ENS

2MSR-Inria Joint Centre


Abstract.

In personalized Federated Learning, each member of a potentially large set of agents aims to train a model minimizing its loss function averaged over its local data distribution. We study this problem under the lens of stochastic optimization. Specifically, we introduce information-theoretic lower bounds on the number of samples required from all agents to approximately minimize the generalization error of a fixed agent. We then provide strategies matching these lower bounds, in the all-for-one and all-for-all settings where respectively one or all agents desire to minimize their own local function. Our strategies are based on a gradient filtering approach: provided prior knowledge on some notions of distances or discrepancies between local data distributions or functions, a given agent filters and aggregates stochastic gradients received from other agents, in order to achieve an optimal bias-variance trade-off.

1. Introduction

A central task in Federated Learning (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Kairouz etÂ al., 2019) is the training of a common model from local data sets held by individual agents. A typical application is when users (e.g.Â mobile phones, hospitals) want to make predictions (e.g.Â next-word prediction, treatment prescriptions), but each has access to very few data samples, hence the need for collaboration. As highlighted by many recent works (e.g.Â Hanzely etÂ al. (2020); Mansour etÂ al. (2020)), while training a global model yields better statistical efficiency on the combined datasets of all agents by increasing the number of samples linearly in the number of agents, this approach can suffer from a dramatically poor generalization error on local datasets. A solution to this generalization issue is the training of personalized models, a midway between a shared model between agents and models trained locally without any coordination.

An ideal approach would take the best of both worlds: increased statistical efficiency by using more samples, while keeping local generalization errors low. This raises the fundamental question: what is the optimal bias/variance tradeoff between personalization and coordination, and how can it be achieved?

We formulate the personalized federated learning problem as follows, studying it under the lens of stochastic optimizationÂ (Bottou etÂ al., 2018). Consider Nâˆˆâ„•âˆ—ğ‘superscriptâ„•N\in\mathbb{N}^{*} agents denoted by integers 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, each desiring to minimize its own local function fi:â„dâ†’â„:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, while sharing their stochastic gradients. Since only a limited number of samples are locally available, we focus on stochastic gradient descent-like algorithms, where agents each sequentially compute stochastic gradients giksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜g_{i}^{k} such that ğ”¼â€‹[gik]=âˆ‡fiğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\mathbb{E}\left[g_{i}^{k}\right]=\nabla f_{i}. In order to reduce the sample complexity, i.e.Â the number of samples or stochastic gradients required to reach small generalization error, agents thus need to use stochastic gradients from other agents, that are biased since in general ğ”¼â€‹[gik]â‰ âˆ‡fjğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—\mathbb{E}\left[g_{i}^{k}\right]\neq\nabla f_{j}. We first consider the all-for-one objective, where a single agent iğ‘–i wants to minimize its local function (local generalization error), using its own information as well as information from agents jâ‰ iğ‘—ğ‘–j\neq i. We then address the all-for-all objective where all agents want to minimize their local function (local generalization error) in parallel using shared information. Our algorithms are based on a gradient filtering approach: in both all-for-one and all-for-all objectives, upon reception of stochastic gradients (gjk)jsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘—(g_{j}^{k})_{j}, agent iğ‘–i filters these gradients and aggregates them using some weights Î»jsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—\lambda_{j} into âˆ‘jÎ»jâ€‹gjksubscriptğ‘—subscriptğœ†ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘—ğ‘˜\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}g_{j}^{k}, in order to achieve some bias/variance trade-off.

Contributions and outline of the paper

In this paper, we consider oracle models where at each step k=1,2,â€¦ğ‘˜12â€¦k=1,2,\dots, one (or all) agent(s) may draw a sample according to its (their) local distribution. We aim at computing the number of stochastic gradients sampled from all agents, required to reach a small generalization error in both all-for-one and all-for-all formulations, in terms of: biases (distances between functions or distributions), regularity and noise assumptions. The oracle models, main assumptions and problem formulations are given in SectionÂ 2. Our main contributions are then as follows:

(i) In SectionÂ 3 we prove information theoretic lower bounds: to reach a target generalization error Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 for a fixed agent iğ‘–i, no algorithm can achieve a reduction in the number of oracle calls by a factor larger than the total number of agents Îµğœ€\varepsilon-close â€“in a suitable senseâ€“ to agent iğ‘–i.

(ii) We next study a weighted gradient averaging algorithm for the all-for-one problem, matching this lower bound.

(iii) We then propose in SectionÂ 5 a parallel extension of the simple weighted gradient averaging algorithm that yields an efficient algorithm for the all-for-all problem. In this algorithm, agents compute stochastic gradients at their local estimate, and broadcast it to other agents who may use these to update their own estimates. For xk=(x1k,â€¦,xNk)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘˜â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘˜x^{k}=(x_{1}^{k},\ldots,x_{N}^{k}) where xiksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{i}^{k} is the local estimate of agent iğ‘–i at iteration kğ‘˜k, updates of the all-for-all algorithm write as:

xk+1=xkâˆ’Î·â€‹Wâ€‹gk,superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğœ‚ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\eta Wg^{k}\,,

where gk=(g1k,â€¦,gNk)superscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘”1ğ‘˜â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘ğ‘˜g^{k}=(g_{1}^{k},...,g_{N}^{k}) for an unbiased stochastic gradientÂ giksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜g_{i}^{k} of function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, a step size Î·ğœ‚\eta, and a carefully chosen matrixÂ Wğ‘ŠW. Agents iğ‘–i thus use stochastic gradients that are doubly biased, as gradients of a â€œwrong functionâ€ fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} instead of fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} computed at a â€œwrong locationâ€ xjksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘—x^{k}_{j} instead of xiksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–x^{k}_{i}.

Related works

Federated Learning is a paradigm in machine learning where training is done collaboratively among several agents, taking into account privacy constraints (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016; Kairouz etÂ al., 2019; Wang etÂ al., 2019). A central task is the training of a common model for all agents, for which both centralized approaches orchestrated by a server and decentralized approaches with no central coordinator (Nedich etÂ al., 2018) have been considered. The algorithms we propose in this paper are well suited for a decentralized implementation.

As observed inÂ Hanzely etÂ al. (2020), training a common model for all users can lead to poor generalization on certain tasks such as e.g. next-word prediction. To improve both accuracy and fairness, personalized models thus need to be learnt for each agent (Li etÂ al., 2020; Mohri etÂ al., 2019; Yu etÂ al., 2021). Approaches to personalization include fine-tuning (Cheng etÂ al., 2021; Khodak etÂ al., 2019), transfer learning techniques (Tripuraneni etÂ al., 2020; Wang etÂ al., 2019). Hanzely etÂ al. (2020); Fallah etÂ al. (2020) among others formulate personalization in FL as the training of local models with a regularization term that enforces collaboration between users. We refer the interested reader to Kulkarni etÂ al. (2020) for a broader survey of Personalized Federated Learning.

While the goal of personalization is to minimize local generalization errors, the above cited works do not provide theoretical guarantees over the sample complexity to obtain small local errors, but instead control errors on a regularized problem, in terms of communication rounds or full gradients used, and not in terms of samples used. Deng etÂ al. (2020); Mansour etÂ al. (2020) among others provide generalization errors under a statistical learning framework that depend on VC-dimensions and on distances between each local data distribution and the mixture of all datasets. Donahue and Kleinberg (2021a, b) study the bias-variance trade-off between collaboration and personalization for mean estimation in a game-theoretic framework. Chayti etÂ al. (2021); Grimberg etÂ al. (2021); Beaussart etÂ al. (2021) frame personalization as a stochastic optimization problem with biased gradients and are the works closest to ours. They consider the training of a single agent with biased gradients from another group of agents, i.e. the all-for-one problem and obtain performance guarantees in terms of distance between individual function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} and the average Nâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘jfjsuperscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—N^{-1}\sum_{j}f_{j}. In contrast, we obtain more general performance bounds based on distance bounds between all pairs of functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} (or equivalently, pairs of local distributions). In addition, we prove matching lower bounds. Finally, we also consider the all-for-all problem, for which we obtain efficient algorithms, and leverage in that setting the use of weaker bias assumptions than in the all-for-one problem.

2. Problem Statement and Assumptions

We now detail our objectives and the necessary technical assumptions. We consider general stochastic gradient methods and formulate our problems, assumptions and algorithms accordingly. Our lower bounds apply to a more specific problem, namely generalization error minimization, or GEM, where functions fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} of all agents jğ‘—j are all obtained from the same loss function â„“â„“\ell. These lower bounds a fortiori apply to the more general stochastic gradient setup of our algorithms.

Stochastic (sub)-gradients

Let fi:â„dâ†’â„:subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f_{i}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N be agent iğ‘–iâ€™s local function to be minimized (e.g.Â the average of a loss function over its local data distribution). At every iteration k=1,2,â€¦ğ‘˜12â€¦k=1,2,\ldots, agent iğ‘–i may access unbiased i.i.d.Â estimates gikâ€‹(x)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¥g_{i}^{k}(x) of âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\nabla f_{i}(x) (or of some subgradient sâ€‹(x)âˆˆâˆ‚fiâ€‹(x)ğ‘ ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥s(x)\in\partial f_{i}(x), depending on the regularity assumptions made):

ğ”¼â€‹[gikâ€‹(x)]âˆˆâˆ‚fiâ€‹(x),xâˆˆâ„d,kâ©¾0,â€‰1â©½iâ©½N.formulae-sequenceğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘formulae-sequenceğ‘˜01ğ‘–ğ‘\mathbb{E}\left[g_{i}^{k}(x)\right]\in\partial f_{i}(x)\,,\quad x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\,,\,k\geqslant 0\,,\,1\leqslant i\leqslant N\,.

We consider two different objectives. In the all-for-one setting, using information from all agents, a fixed agent iğ‘–i desires to minimize its own local function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} (typically, in collaborative GEM, fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is the generalization error fiâ€‹(x)=ğ”¼ğ’Ÿiâ€‹[â„“â€‹(x,Î¾i)]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–delimited-[]â„“ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–f_{i}(x)=\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}[\ell(x,\xi_{i})]). In the all-for-all setting, all agents want to minimize their own local function, using shared information.

Oracle models

To specify the information shared between agents via access to stochastic gradients, we define the following oracles. The synchronous oracle (resp.Â asynchronous oracle) lets at every iteration all agents (resp.Â only one agent) sample a stochastic gradient. After Kğ¾K queries from the synchronous oracle (resp.Â asynchronous oracle), each agent will have sampled Kğ¾K (resp.Â K/Nğ¾ğ‘K/N on average) stochastic gradients for a total of Nâ€‹Kğ‘ğ¾NK (resp.Â Kğ¾K) in the whole set of agents. In the all-for-one setting where a fixed agent iğ‘–i desires to minimize its own local function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, all agents jğ‘—j can take the same xjk=xiksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{j}^{k}=x_{i}^{k} as argument of their stochastic gradient, resulting in a simple stochastic gradient descent with biased gradients. The difficulty in analyzing all-for-all algorithms lies in the fact that stochastic gradients sampled by agent jğ‘—j are doubly biased for agent iğ‘–i, being potentially computed at some xjksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘˜x_{j}^{k} distinct from xiksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{i}^{k}.

Synchronous and asynchronous oracles At iterations k=1,2,â€¦ğ‘˜12â€¦k=1,2,...: 1: A set of agents Sksuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S^{k} is chosen: Sk={1,â€¦,N}superscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜1â€¦ğ‘S^{k}={{\left\{1,\ldots,N\right\}}} for the synchronous oracle, Sk={ik}superscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜S^{k}={{\left\{i_{k}\right\}}} where iksubscriptğ‘–ğ‘˜i_{k} is sampled uniformly at random amongst agents, for the asynchronous oracle. ; 2: For all jâˆˆSkğ‘—superscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜j\in S^{k}, agent jğ‘—j chooses some yjksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—ğ‘˜y_{j}^{k} as a (possibly random) function of all previous stochastic gradients and iterates, and samples gjkâ€‹(yjk)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘—ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—ğ‘˜g_{j}^{k}(y_{j}^{k}); 3: All agents can then perform an update using these new stochastic gradients and all previous ones.

For fixed target precision Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, the objective is to find, using TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} samples from all agents in total, queried with synchronous or asynchronous oracles, models with local generalization error Îµğœ€\varepsilon. We prove matching lower and upper bounds on the sample complexity TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} in the all-for-one and all-for-all settings.

Regularity, Bias and Noise Assumptions

Throughout the paper, we assume that each function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is minimized over â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}, and we denote by xiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†x_{i}^{\star} such a minimizer.

Bias assumptions on function discrepancies. For some non-negative weights (biâ€‹j)1â©½i,jâ©½Nâˆˆâ„+NÃ—Nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—formulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘(b_{ij})_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\in{\mathbb{R}^{+}}^{N\times N}, (b~iâ€‹j)1â©½i,jâ©½Nâˆˆâ„+NÃ—Nsubscriptsubscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—formulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘(\tilde{b}_{ij})_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\in{\mathbb{R}^{+}}^{N\times N} and mâ©¾0ğ‘š0m\geqslant 0, either one of the two following assumptions will be made. Note that if differentiable, we have ğ”¼â€‹[gikâ€‹(x)]=âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\mathbb{E}\left[g_{i}^{k}(x)\right]=\nabla f_{i}(x).

  1. B.1

    For all 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, optimal model xjâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†x_{j}^{\star} for jğ‘—j generalizes (with generalization error biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—b_{ij}) for agent iğ‘–i:

    fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½biâ€‹j.subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant b_{ij}\,. (1)
  2. B.2

    For all 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N and for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, kâ©¾0ğ‘˜0k\geqslant 0:

    â€–ğ”¼â€‹[gikâ€‹(x)]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[gjkâ€‹(x)]â€–2â©½b~iâ€‹j.superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¥ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘¥2subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—{{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[g_{i}^{k}(x)\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[g_{j}^{k}(x)\right]\right\|}}^{2}\leqslant\tilde{b}_{ij}\,. (2)

Two sets of regularity and noise assumptions. The two different noise and regularity assumptions we shall consider are as follows.

  1. N.1

    For all 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is convex and for some B>0ğµ0B>0, all kâ©¾1ğ‘˜1k\geqslant 1 and xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

    ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gikâ€‹(x)â€–2]â©½B2.ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¥2superscriptğµ2\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{i}^{k}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant B^{2}\,. (3)
  2. N.2

    For all 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex, Lğ¿L-smooth, and we write Îº=LÎ¼ğœ…ğ¿ğœ‡\kappa=\frac{L}{\mu}. For Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0, all kâ©¾1ğ‘˜1k\geqslant 1 and xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}:

    ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gikâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)â€–2]â©½Ïƒ2.ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥2superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{i}^{k}(x)-\nabla f_{i}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant\sigma^{2}\,. (4)

Our regularity assumptions are standard111In fact our approach could be extended to other regularity assumptions, e.g. functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} withÂ Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0 as in AppendixÂ E.4, non-convex, or satisfying a Polyak-Lojasiewicz inequality; we do not pursue this here for lack of space. We also generalize (B.2) to function dissimilarities such as those in Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020), in AppendixÂ D, (B.3).; our bias (and gradient dissimilarity) assumptions are less classical, and can be derived from Wassertstein-like distribution-based distances in the GEM setting (SectionÂ 6 and AppendixÂ A). AssumptionÂ (B.2) will be used in the all-for-one setting, while the less restrictiveÂ (B.1) will be used in the all-for-all setting. It quantifies by how much agentsâ€™ objectives differ. To the best of our knowledge it has not been previously used in Federated Learning. It is related to (B.2) through fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½12â€‹Î¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â€–2=12â€‹Î¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)â€–2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†12ğœ‡superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†212ğœ‡superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†2f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant\frac{1}{2\mu}{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right\|}}^{2}=\frac{1}{2\mu}{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})\right\|}}^{2} under Î¼ğœ‡\mu-PL or strong convexity assumptions. More generally, we always have fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½â€–xiâ‹†âˆ’xjâ‹†â€–â€‹â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)â€–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant{{\left\|x_{i}^{\star}-x_{j}^{\star}\right\|}}{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})\right\|}}. Our lower bounds apply to functions that verify both these bias assumptions, and a fortiori verify the assumptions made in our upper bounds where only one of these bias assumptions is required.

Finally, our upper bounds will use the following settings, that we refer to as SettingÂ 1 and SettingÂ 2:

  1. (1)

    Asynchronous oracle is used, assumptionÂ (N.1) holds.

  2. (2)

    Synchronous oracle is used, assumptionÂ (N.2) holds.

A key instance of our problem is collaborative generalization error minimization (GEM): let ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} for 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N be a probability distribution on a set ÎÎ\Xi (agent iğ‘–iâ€™s local distribution, not its empirical distribution), â„“:ğ’³Ã—Îâ†’â„:â„“â†’ğ’³Îâ„\ell:\mathcal{X}\times\Xi\to\mathbb{R} a loss function, and define the following local objective function, that agent iğ‘–i aims at minimizing:

fiâ€‹(x)=ğ”¼Î¾iâˆ¼ğ’Ÿiâ€‹[â„“â€‹(x,Î¾i)],xâˆˆğ’³.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–delimited-[]â„“ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ’³f_{i}(x)=\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}\left[\ell(x,\xi_{i})\right]\,,\quad x\in\mathcal{X}\,. (5)

Function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is thus the generalization error on agent iğ‘–iâ€™s local distribution. Stochastic gradients are in that case of the form gikâ€‹(x)=âˆ‡xâ„“â€‹(x,Î¾ik)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥â„“ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘˜g_{i}^{k}(x)=\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi_{i}^{k}) where Î¾ikâˆ¼ğ’Ÿisimilar-tosuperscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\xi_{i}^{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}. Counting the number of stochastic gradients used in the whole set of agents to reach a precision Îµğœ€\varepsilon for fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} thus reduces to computing the number of samples required from all agents to obtain local generalization error Îµğœ€\varepsilon for agent iğ‘–i. In AppendixÂ A we discuss how our bias assumptions follow from bounds on distances between distributions ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}, ğ’Ÿjsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—\mathcal{D}_{j} together with practical scenarios where such bounds can be obtained.

Notation: in the rest of the paper, variables tğ‘¡t or Tğ‘‡T denote the number of stochastic gradients giksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜g_{i}^{k} sampled (or data item sampled from personal distribution) from all agents, while variables kğ‘˜k or Kğ¾K denote the iterates of the algorithms or equivalently to the number of oracle calls made.

3. IT Lower Bounds on the Sample Complexity

In this section, we prove lower bounds on the sample complexity of the all-for-one problem. Our lower bounds apply to collaborative GEM, i.e. functions (fi)1â©½iâ©½Nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘(f_{i})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N} of the formÂ (5), for some shared loss function â„“â„“\ell and user distributions ğ’Ÿ1,â€¦,ğ’ŸNsubscriptğ’Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘\mathcal{D}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{D}_{N}.

An oracle Ï•:â„NÃ—dâ†’â„:italic-Ï•â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘‘â„\phi:\mathbb{R}^{N\times d}\to\mathcal{I} is a random function that answers some Ï•â€‹(x)âˆˆâ„italic-Ï•ğ‘¥â„\phi(x)\in\mathcal{I} where â„â„\mathcal{I} is an information set, for every query xâˆˆâ„NÃ—dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d}. We adapt the definitions ofÂ Agarwal etÂ al. (2012) of sample complexity for SGD to our personalization problem. Formally, the first-order oracle we defined in SectionÂ 2 (for either synchronous or asynchronous oracles) and that we write as Ï•â€‹((ğ’Ÿi)i=1,â€¦,N,â„“)italic-Ï•subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘â„“\phi\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{i=1,\ldots,N},\ell\big{)} for shared loss function â„“â„“\ell and user distributions ğ’Ÿ1,â€¦,ğ’ŸNsubscriptğ’Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘\mathcal{D}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{D}_{N}, returns for xâˆˆâ„NÃ—dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d}:

Ï•â€‹((ğ’Ÿi)i,â„“)â€‹(x)=(i,xi,Î¾i,â„“â€‹(xi,Î¾i),gikâ€‹(xi))iâˆˆSk,italic-Ï•subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘–â„“ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–â„“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–superscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜\phi\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{i},\ell\big{)}(x)=\Big{(}i,\,x_{i},\,\xi_{i},\,\ell(x_{i},\xi_{i}),\,g_{i}^{k}(x_{i})\Big{)}_{i\in S^{k}}\,,

where Î¾iâˆ¼ğ’Ÿisimilar-tosubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\xi_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i} and Sksuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S^{k} is the set of agents returning a stochastic gradient at step kğ‘˜k, according to the synchronous or asynchronous oracle in use. Given distributions and a loss function ((ğ’Ÿi)i,â„“)subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘–â„“\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{i},\ell\big{)}, we denote by ğ•„ğ•„\mathbb{M} the set of all methods â„³=(â„³T)Tâ©¾0â„³subscriptsubscriptâ„³ğ‘‡ğ‘‡0\mathcal{M}=(\mathcal{M}_{T})_{T\geqslant 0}: for any Tâ©¾0ğ‘‡0T\geqslant 0, â„³Tsubscriptâ„³ğ‘‡\mathcal{M}_{T} makes Kğ¾K oracle calls from oracle Ï•â€‹((ğ’Ÿi)i,â„“)italic-Ï•subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘–â„“\phi\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{i},\ell\big{)} while using Tğ‘‡T stochastic gradient samples from all agents (T=Nâ€‹Kğ‘‡ğ‘ğ¾T=NK with the synchronous oracle, T=Kğ‘‡ğ¾T=K with the asynchronous oracle), and returns xiTâˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘‡superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}^{T}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for agent iğ‘–i. For a set ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D} of couples of distributions and loss function ((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“)subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell\big{)} defining functions (fi)1â©½iâ©½Nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘(f_{i})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}, we are interested in lower-bounding:

infâ„³âˆˆğ•„sup((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“)âˆˆğ”»ğ’¯iÎµâ€‹(â„³,((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“)),subscriptinfimumâ„³ğ•„subscriptsupremumsubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“ğ”»superscriptsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘–ğœ€â„³subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“\inf_{\mathcal{M}\in\mathbb{M}}\sup_{((\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell)\in\mathbb{D}}\mathcal{T}_{i}^{\varepsilon}\Big{(}\mathcal{M},\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell\big{)}\Big{)}\,,

where ğ’¯iÎµâ€‹(â„³,((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“))superscriptsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘–ğœ€â„³subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“\mathcal{T}_{i}^{\varepsilon}\Big{(}\mathcal{M},\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell\big{)}\Big{)} is the number of samples required from all agents (uniformly divided between agents) to reach generalization error Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 for agentÂ iğ‘–i and writes as:

inf{Tâˆˆâ„•âˆ—â€‹such thatâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[fiâ€‹(xiT)âˆ’minxâˆˆğ’³â¡fiâ€‹(x)]â©½Îµ}.infimumğ‘‡superscriptâ„•such thatğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¥ğ’³subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğœ€\displaystyle\inf{{\left\{T\in\mathbb{N}^{*}\,\text{such that}\,\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{T})-\min_{x\in\mathcal{X}}f_{i}(x)\right]\leqslant\varepsilon\right\}}}\,.

For (biâ€‹j)âˆˆâ„+NÃ—Nsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘(b_{ij})\in{\mathbb{R}^{+}}^{N\times N}, r>0ğ‘Ÿ0r>0, B>0ğµ0B>0, let ğ”»â€‹(r,b,B)ğ”»ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµ\mathbb{D}(r,b,B) be the set of all ((ğ’Ÿi)1â©½iâ©½N,â„“)subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘â„“\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N},\ell\big{)} for probability distributions (ğ’Ÿi)1â©½iâ©½Nsubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N} on a probability space ÎâŠ‚â„DÎsuperscriptâ„ğ·\Xi\subset\mathbb{R}^{D} such that all functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} parameterized by the losses and distributions in this set verify â€–xiâ‹†â€–â©½rnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğ‘Ÿ{{\left\|x_{i}^{\star}\right\|}}\leqslant r, assumptionÂ (N.1), and bias assumptions (B.1) andÂ (B.2) for bğ‘b and b~iâ€‹j=(biâ€‹j/r)2subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘Ÿ2\tilde{b}_{ij}=(b_{ij}/r)^{2}.

Similarly, for Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0, Î¼,L>0ğœ‡ğ¿0\mu,L>0, let ğ”»Î¼Lâ€‹(r,b,B)superscriptsubscriptğ”»ğœ‡ğ¿ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµ\mathbb{D}_{\mu}^{L}(r,b,B) be the set of all ((ğ’Ÿi)1â©½iâ©½N,â„“)subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘â„“\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N},\ell\big{)} for probability distributions (ğ’Ÿi)1â©½iâ©½Nsubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N} on a probability space ÎâŠ‚â„DÎsuperscriptâ„ğ·\Xi\subset\mathbb{R}^{D} such that all functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} parameterized by this set verify â€–xiâ‹†â€–â©½rnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğ‘Ÿ{{\left\|x_{i}^{\star}\right\|}}\leqslant r, assumptionÂ (N.2), and bias assumptionsÂ (B.1) andÂ (B.2) for bğ‘b and b~=Î¼â€‹b~ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘\tilde{b}=\mu b here.

Theorem 1 (IT lower bound).

Let Îµâˆˆ(0,1/16)ğœ€0116\varepsilon\in(0,1/16), and assume that either the synchronous or asynchronous oracle is used, that (biâ€‹j)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—(b_{ij}) verifies the triangle inequality biâ€‹jâ©½biâ€‹k+bkâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—b_{ij}\leqslant b_{ik}+b_{kj} for all 1â©½i,j,kâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘1\leqslant i,j,k\leqslant N. For some constant C>0ğ¶0C>0 independent of the problem and any iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}:

infâ„³âˆˆğ•„sup((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“)âˆˆğ”»â€‹(r,b,B)ğ’¯iÎµâ€‹(â„³,((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“))â©¾Câ€‹r2â€‹B2â€‹NÎµ2â€‹ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b4),subscriptinfimumâ„³ğ•„subscriptsupremumsubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“ğ”»ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘–ğœ€â„³subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“ğ¶superscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptğµ2ğ‘superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘4\inf_{\mathcal{M}\in\mathbb{M}}\!\sup_{((\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell)\in\mathbb{D}(r,b,B)}\!\!\!\!\!\!\mathcal{T}_{i}^{\varepsilon}\Big{(}\mathcal{M},\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell\big{)}\Big{)}\!\geqslant\!\frac{Cr^{2}B^{2}N}{\varepsilon^{2}\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(\frac{b}{4})}\,,

where ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b)=âˆ‘jğŸ™{biâ€‹jâ©½Îµ}superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘subscriptğ‘—subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(b)=\sum_{j}\mathds{1}_{\{b_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon\}} is the number of agents jğ‘—j verifying biâ€‹jâ©½Îµsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€b_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon. Under strong-convexity and smoothness assumptions for Î¼=L=1/r2ğœ‡ğ¿1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2\mu=L=1/r^{2}, we have, for some Câ€²>0superscriptğ¶â€²0C^{\prime}>0:

infâ„³âˆˆğ•„sup((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“)âˆˆğ”»Î¼=1/r2L=1/r2â€‹(r,b,Ïƒ)ğ’¯iÎµâ€‹(â„³,((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“))â©¾Câ€²â€‹r2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹NÎµâ€‹ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b4).subscriptinfimumâ„³ğ•„subscriptsupremumsubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“superscriptsubscriptğ”»ğœ‡1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ¿1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘–ğœ€â„³subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“superscriptğ¶â€²superscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptğœ2ğ‘ğœ€superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘4\inf_{\mathcal{M}\in\mathbb{M}}\!\sup_{((\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell)\in\mathbb{D}_{\mu=1/r^{2}}^{L=1/r^{2}}(r,b,\sigma)}\!\!\!\!\!\!\mathcal{T}_{i}^{\varepsilon}\Big{(}\mathcal{M},\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell\big{)}\Big{)}\geqslant\frac{C^{\prime}r^{2}\sigma^{2}N}{\varepsilon\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(\frac{b}{4})}\,.

The proof of these lower bounds (AppendixÂ B) builds on lower bounds based on Fanoâ€™s inequality (Duchi and Wainwright, 2013) for stochastic gradient descentÂ Agarwal etÂ al. (2012) or for information limited statistical estimationÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2013; Duchi and Rogers, 2019), adapted to personalization.

Lower-bound interpretation. TheoremÂ 1 states that, given the knowledge of (biâ€‹j)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—(b_{ij}) and B2superscriptğµ2B^{2} (orÂ Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, Î¼ğœ‡\mu and Lğ¿L), there exist difficult instances of the problem that satisfy assumptionÂ (N.1) (orÂ (N.2)) and both bias assumptionsÂ (B.1) andÂ (B.2) for bğ‘b, such that the number of samples from all agents (generated through the synchronous or asynchronous oracle) needed to obtain a generalization error of Îµğœ€\varepsilon for an agent iğ‘–i is lower-bounded by the right hand sides of the equations in TheoremÂ 1.

Collaboration speedup. The factor NÃ—Câ€‹B2â€‹r2â€‹Îµâˆ’2ğ‘ğ¶superscriptğµ2superscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptğœ€2N\times CB^{2}r^{2}\varepsilon^{-2} is reminiscent of stochastic gradient descent, and is present inÂ Agarwal etÂ al. (2012): without cooperation, this is the sample complexity of SGD for a fixed agent (for Tğ‘‡T samples from all agents, only T/Nğ‘‡ğ‘T/N are taken from a given agent iğ‘–i). Cooperation appears in the factor 1/ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b/4)1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘41/\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(b/4): the sample complexity is inversely proportional to the number of agents jğ‘—j that have functions (or distributions) similar to that of iğ‘–i. One cannot hope for better than a linear speedup proportional to agents Îµ/4ğœ€4\varepsilon/4-close to iğ‘–i, in the sense that the functions parameterized by the loss function and distributions verify fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½biâ€‹j/4subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—4f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant b_{ij}/4 and â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fjâ€‹(x)â€–2â©½b~iâ€‹jsuperscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥2subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\leqslant\tilde{b}_{ij} for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where b~=(b/r)2~ğ‘superscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿ2\tilde{b}=(b/r)^{2} in the first case, and b~=b/r2=Î¼â€‹b~ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğœ‡ğ‘\tilde{b}=b/r^{2}=\mu b in the second.

Bias assumptions and collaborative GEM. In SectionÂ 6, we relate â€–âˆ‡fiâˆ’âˆ‡fjâ€–normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}-\nabla f_{j}\right\|}} to distribution-based distances dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)subscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j}) in the GEM setting, where dâ„‹subscriptğ‘‘â„‹d_{\mathcal{H}} is a 1-Wassertstein-like distance. We prove that the distributions leading to the functions used to prove TheoremÂ 1 verify dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant b_{ij}; thus, the distribution based distances also sharply characterize the sample complexity. The requirement for the lower bound to apply that (biâ€‹j)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—(b_{ij}) verifies the triangle inequality is thus quite natural, when translating bias assumptions into distribution-based distances.

4. Weighted Gradient Averaging is optimal in the All-for-one setting

We now prove that a weighted gradient averaging (WGA) algorithm is optimal in the all-for-one setting. Fix the agentÂ iğ‘–i who desires to minimize its local function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} (no longer assumed to derive from a loss function). The iterates of the weighted gradient averaging algorithm write as, for both synchronous and asynchronous oracles:

xk+1=xkâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»jâ€‹Gkâ€‹(x)j,superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—superscriptğºğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\eta\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}G^{k}(x)_{j}\,, (6)

for some step size Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0 and stochastic vector Î»âˆˆâ„Nğœ†superscriptâ„ğ‘\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N}, and:

Gk(x)i={Nâ€‹ğŸ™{i=ik}â€‹gikkâ€‹(x)(asynchronous)gikâ€‹(x)(synchronous oracle).G^{k}(x)_{i}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &N\mathds{1}_{{{\left\{i=i_{k}\right\}}}}g_{i_{k}}^{k}(x)\quad\text{(asynchronous)}\\ &g_{i}^{k}(x)\,\,\,\,\,\quad\quad\quad\text{(synchronous oracle)}\,.\end{aligned}\right. (7)

In the WGA algorithm, all agents involved keep the same local estimates xiksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜x_{i}^{k}. As defined in SectionÂ 2, (gik)superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘˜(g_{i}^{k}) are i.i.d.Â non-biased stochastic (sub)gradients of functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}. The WGA algorithm thus defined is more general than previous ones, through the introduction of parameterÂ Î»ğœ†\lambda. In the GEM setting, WGA is equivalent to training a model on the mixture of distributions (ğ’Ÿj)jsubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—(\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j}, with weights (Î»j)jsubscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—ğ‘—(\lambda_{j})_{j}. We have the following convergence guarantees in terms of sample complexity for the minimization of a function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} with WGA iterations.

Theorem 2.

Let Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, and set Î»j=ğŸ™{biâ€‹j<Îµ/2}ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\lambda_{j}=\frac{\mathds{1}_{{{\left\{b_{ij}<\varepsilon/2\right\}}}}}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}, ğ’©iÎµsuperscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon} being defined in TheoremÂ 1. Generate (xk)ksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘˜(x^{k})_{k} usingÂ (6).

  1. 2.1

    Under SettingÂ 1. Assume that for all kâ©¾0ğ‘˜0k\geqslant 0 and iğ‘–i, â€–xkâˆ’xiâ‹†â€–â©½Dnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğ·{{\left\|x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\right\|}}\leqslant D for some D>0ğ·0D>0 and bias assumptionÂ (B.2) holds for b~=(b/D)2~ğ‘superscriptğ‘ğ·2\tilde{b}=(b/D)^{2}. For K=TÎµğ¾subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€K=T_{\varepsilon} and for Î·=D22â€‹Kâ€‹Nâ€‹B2â€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»j2ğœ‚superscriptğ·22ğ¾ğ‘superscriptğµ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2\eta=\sqrt{\frac{D^{2}}{2KNB^{2}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}^{2}}}, we have ğ”¼â€‹[1Kâ€‹âˆ‘0â©½k<Kfiâ€‹(xk)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)]â©½Îµğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ¾subscript0ğ‘˜ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ€\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{0\leqslant k<K}f_{i}(x^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]\leqslant\varepsilon using a total number TÎµâ€‹(i)subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ‘–T_{\varepsilon}(i) of stochastic gradients from all agents of:

    TÎµâ€‹(i)â©½4â€‹D2â€‹B2Îµ2â€‹Nğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ‘–4superscriptğ·2superscriptğµ2superscriptğœ€2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}(i)\leqslant\frac{4D^{2}B^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\,.\vspace{-7pt}
  2. 2.2

    Under SettingÂ 2. Denote Îº=L/Î¼ğœ…ğ¿ğœ‡\kappa=L/\mu, assume that one of bias assumptionsÂ (B.2) orÂ (B.3) holds for b~=Î¼â€‹b~ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘\tilde{b}=\mu b (and any mâ©¾0ğ‘š0m\geqslant 0). For K=TÎµ/Nğ¾subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ‘K=T_{\varepsilon}/N and Î·=minâ¡(1/(2â€‹L),1Î¼â€‹Kâ€‹lnâ¡(FÎ»0â€‹Î¼2â€‹KLâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆ‘jÎ»j2))ğœ‚12ğ¿1ğœ‡ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğœ†0superscriptğœ‡2ğ¾ğ¿superscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2\eta=\min(1/(2L),\frac{1}{\mu K}\ln(\frac{F_{\lambda}^{0}\mu^{2}K}{L\sigma^{2}}\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}^{2})) where FÎ»0=âˆ‘jÎ»jâ€‹(fjâ€‹(x0)âˆ’fjâ€‹(xjâ‹†))superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğœ†0subscriptğ‘—subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†F_{\lambda}^{0}=\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}(f_{j}(x^{0})-f_{j}(x_{j}^{\star})), we have ğ”¼â€‹[fiâ€‹(xK)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)]â©½Îµğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ€\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x^{K})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]\leqslant\varepsilon using a total number TÎµâ€‹(i)subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ‘–T_{\varepsilon}(i) of stochastic gradients from all agents of:

    TÎµâ€‹(i)â©½ğ’ª~â€‹(Îºâ€‹Ïƒ2Î¼â€‹Îµâ€‹Nğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ‘–~ğ’ªğœ…superscriptğœ2ğœ‡ğœ€ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}(i)\leqslant\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\kappa\sigma^{2}}{\mu\varepsilon}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\right)\,.

The personalization-dependent factor of both these sample complexities (the second factor Nğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}) matches that of the lower bound in TheoremÂ 1. While in TheoremÂ 2.1 upper and lower bounds (up to constant factors) exactly match, in the strongly convex and smooth case (TheoremÂ 2.2), the lower bound is for Îº=1ğœ…1\kappa=1, and in that particular case, lower and upper bounds match; we conjecture that in the more general case, the optimal sample complexity as a linear dependency in Îºğœ…\sqrt{\kappa}. In terms of gradient filtering, an optimal strategy is thus to filter and keep stochastic gradients sent by agents that are Îµğœ€\varepsilon-close, in the sense ofÂ (B.2). TheoremÂ 4 presents a tuning of the algorithm for a fixed target precision Îµğœ€\varepsilon; using a doubling trick as we do in AppendixÂ E.3 yields time-adaptive algorithms, that achieve the same sample complexity (up to constant factors) for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0.

In the GEM setting, the proposed WGA algorithm consists in training a model over the distribution ğ’ŸiÎµsuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğœ€\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\varepsilon}, a mixture of the distributions {ğ’Ÿj:dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½Îµ/2}conditional-setsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğœ€2{{\left\{\mathcal{D}_{j}\,:\,d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant\varepsilon/2\right\}}}, where dâ„‹subscriptğ‘‘â„‹d_{\mathcal{H}} is a distribution-based distance, leading to an increase in the number of samples available by a factor ğ’©iÎµsuperscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon} (thus reducing the variance), while keeping the bias of order Îµğœ€\varepsilon.

5. All-for-all Strategies

We now focus on the more challenging all-for-all setting: all agents desire to minimize their local function. We first present a naive approach, that proves to be sample-optimal, but that cannot be used in practice for large scale problems, as it requires a number computations per oracle call for each agent that increases with Nğ‘N. We thus introduce and analyze the all-for-all algorithm, the main algorithmic contribution of our paper.

Naive Approach

Each agent iğ‘–i keeps Nğ‘N shared local models x1k,â€¦,xNksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘˜â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘˜x_{1}^{k},\ldots,x_{N}^{k}, where xjksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘˜x_{j}^{k} estimates xjâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†x_{j}^{\star} at iteration kğ‘˜k (the knowledge of xjksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ‘˜x_{j}^{k} needs to be shared by all agents). At each iteration kğ‘˜k, when a sample Î¾jksubscriptsuperscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜ğ‘—\xi^{k}_{j} is obtained at agent jğ‘—j, it is used by that agent to compute unbiased estimates of âˆ‡fjâ€‹(xik)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–\nabla f_{j}(x^{k}_{i}) for all iâˆˆ[N]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[N]. These are then broadcast to all agents iğ‘–i that verify biâ€‹jâ©½Îµsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€b_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon (target precision). Agents then perform Nğ‘N weighted gradient averaging algorithms simultaneously, leading to the following guarantees. Under the assumptions of TheoremÂ 2.1, we have max1â©½iâ©½Nâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[fiâ€‹(xik)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)]â©½Îµsubscript1ğ‘–ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ€\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]\leqslant\varepsilon, with a number of data items sampled from personal distribution TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} of:

TÎµâ©½4â€‹D2â€‹B2Îµ2â€‹max1â©½iâ©½Nâ¡Nğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€4superscriptğ·2superscriptğµ2superscriptğœ€2subscript1ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\frac{4D^{2}B^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\,.

Under the assumptions of TheoremÂ 2.2, we have max1â©½iâ©½Nâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[fiâ€‹(xik)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)]â©½Îµsubscript1ğ‘–ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ€\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]\leqslant\varepsilon, with a number of data item sampled from personal distribution TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} of:

TÎµâ©½ğ’ª~â€‹(Îºâ€‹Ïƒ2Î¼â€‹Îµâ€‹max1â©½iâ©½Nâ¡Nğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€~ğ’ªğœ…superscriptğœ2ğœ‡ğœ€subscript1ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\kappa\sigma^{2}}{\mu\varepsilon}\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\right)\,.

Using the all-for-one lower bounds of TheoremÂ 1, this proves to be optimal. Yet, the memory requirements and computation/communication costs of this approach are forbiddingly high for large Nğ‘N (they scale with ğ’©iÎµsuperscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon} for agent iğ‘–i), hence the all-for-all algorithm below, that relaxes the metric considered by controlling the averaged local errors Nâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘1â©½iâ©½Nğ”¼â€‹[fiâ€‹(xik)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)]superscriptğ‘1subscript1ğ‘–ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†N^{-1}\sum_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right] instead of worst-case ones max1â©½iâ©½Nâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[fiâ€‹(xik)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)]subscript1ğ‘–ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†\max_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]. Furthermore, relaxing the quantity controlled leads to weaker necessary bias assumptions.

The All-for-all algorithm

We now present the all-for-all algorithm (AFA), an adaptation of the weighted gradient averaging algorithm to the all-for-all setting, where all agents desire to use all stochastic gradients computed. For 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, initialize xi0=x0âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘¥0superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}^{0}=x_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. At iteration kğ‘˜k, let xikâˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}^{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} be agent iğ‘–iâ€™s current estimate of xiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†x_{i}^{\star}, and denote xk=(xik)1â©½iâ©½Nâˆˆâ„NÃ—dsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘–ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘‘x^{k}=(x_{i}^{k})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d}. For a step size Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0 and a symmetric non-negative matrix Wâˆˆâ„NÃ—Nğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘W\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N}, iterates of the all-for-all algorithm are generated with AlgorithmÂ 1. In TheoremÂ 3, we control the averaged local generalization error amongst all agents:

Fk=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(xik)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†),kâ©¾0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ¹ğ‘˜1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğ‘˜0F^{k}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i}^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\,,\quad k\geqslant 0\,.
Theorem 3 (All-for-all algorithm).

Let K>0ğ¾0K>0, Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0, and Wğ‘ŠW a symmetric non-negative random matrix of the form W=Î›â€‹Î›âŠ¤ğ‘ŠÎ›superscriptÎ›topW=\Lambda\Lambda^{\top} for some stochastic matrix Î›=(Î»iâ€‹j)1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ›subscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—formulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘\Lambda=(\lambda_{ij})_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}. Let (xik)kâ©¾0,1â©½iâ©½Nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜formulae-sequenceğ‘˜01ğ‘–ğ‘(x_{i}^{k})_{k\geqslant 0,1\leqslant i\leqslant N} be generated with AlgorithmÂ 1. Assume that bias assumptionÂ (B.1) holds for some (biâ€‹j)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—(b_{ij}).

  1. 3.a

    Under Setting 1. Using step size Î·=2â€‹Nâ€‹â€–x0âˆ’xÎ›â€–2Kâ€‹B2â€‹âˆ‘i,jÎ»iâ€‹j2ğœ‚2ğ‘superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥Î›2ğ¾superscriptğµ2subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—2\eta=\sqrt{\frac{2N{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\Lambda}\right\|}}^{2}}{KB^{2}\sum_{i,j}\lambda_{ij}^{2}}}:

    ğ”¼â€‹[1Kâ€‹âˆ‘k=0Kâˆ’1Fk]ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¾1superscriptğ¹ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}F^{k}\right]\! â©½2â€‹B2â€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâ€–xi0âˆ’xiÎ›â€–2Nâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹j2absent2superscriptğµ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Î›2ğ‘ğ¾subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—2\displaystyle\!\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2B^{2}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{{\left\|x_{i}^{0}-x_{i}^{\Lambda}\right\|}}^{2}}{NK}\!\!\!\!\!\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}^{2}}
    +1Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹biâ€‹j,1ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle+\frac{1}{N}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}b_{ij}\,,
  2. 3.b

    Under Setting 2. If Î·=1Î¼â€‹Kâ€‹lnâ¡(Nâ€‹F0â€‹Î¼2â€‹KLâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆ‘iâ€‹jÎ»iâ€‹j2)âˆ§12â€‹Lğœ‚1ğœ‡ğ¾ğ‘superscriptğ¹0superscriptğœ‡2ğ¾ğ¿superscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—212ğ¿\eta=\frac{1}{\mu K}\ln(\frac{NF^{0}\mu^{2}K}{L\sigma^{2}\sum_{ij}\lambda_{ij}^{2}})\wedge\frac{1}{2L}:

    ğ”¼â€‹[FK]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ¹ğ¾\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F^{K}\right] â©½F0â€‹eâˆ’K2â€‹Îº+ğ’ª~â€‹(Lâ€‹Ïƒ2Kâ€‹Î¼2â€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹j2)absentsuperscriptğ¹0superscriptğ‘’ğ¾2ğœ…~ğ’ªğ¿superscriptğœ2ğ¾superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—2\displaystyle\leqslant F^{0}e^{-\frac{K}{2\kappa}}+\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{L\sigma^{2}}{K\mu^{2}N}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}^{2}\right)
    +1Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹biâ€‹j.1ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle+\frac{1}{N}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}b_{ij}\,.

In 3.a, xÎ›superscriptğ‘¥Î›x^{\Lambda} is a minimizer of the functionÂ (8). In terms of sample complexity, we have the following.

Theorem 4 (All-for-all sample complexity).

Let Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, and set W=Î›â€‹Î›âŠ¤ğ‘ŠÎ›superscriptÎ›topW=\Lambda\Lambda^{\top} for Î»iâ€‹j=ğŸ™{biâ€‹j<Îµ/2}ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\lambda_{ij}=\frac{\mathds{1}_{{\left\{b_{ij}<\varepsilon/2\right\}}}}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}.

  1. (1)

    Under the same assumptions as in TheoremÂ 3.a, we have ğ”¼â€‹[1Kâ€‹âˆ‘k=0Kâˆ’1Fk]â©½Îµğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¾1superscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğœ€\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}F^{k}\right]\leqslant\varepsilon for a total number TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} of data item sampled from personal distribution from all agents of:

    TÎµâ©½4â€‹D2â€‹B2Îµ2â€‹âˆ‘i=1N1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b),subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€4superscriptğ·2superscriptğµ2superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\frac{4D^{2}B^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\,,

    where D2superscriptğ·2D^{2} bounds all â€–xi0âˆ’xiÎ›â€–2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Î›2{{\left\|x_{i}^{0}-x_{i}^{\Lambda}\right\|}}^{2}, 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N.

  2. (2)

    Under the same assumptions as in TheoremÂ 3.b, we have ğ”¼â€‹[FK]â©½Îµğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ¹ğ¾ğœ€\mathbb{E}\left[F^{K}\right]\leqslant\varepsilon for a total number TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} of data item sampled from personal distribution from all agents of:

    TÎµâ©½2â€‹maxâ¡(Îºâ€‹Ïƒ2Îµâ€‹Î¼â€‹âˆ‘i=1N1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b),Nâ€‹Îº)â€‹lnâ¡(Îµâˆ’1â€‹F0).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€2ğœ…superscriptğœ2ğœ€ğœ‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘ğ‘ğœ…superscriptğœ€1superscriptğ¹0T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant 2\max\left(\frac{\kappa\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon\mu}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)},\,N\kappa\right)\ln\big{(}\varepsilon^{-1}F^{0}\big{)}\,.

Collaborative speedup. In SettingÂ 1, denoting TÎµâ€‹(i)subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ‘–T_{\varepsilon}(i) the sample complexity in the all-for-one setting (that matched the corresponding lower bound), we observe that in the all-for-all regime, we obtain TÎµâ©½1Nâ€‹âˆ‘iTÎµâ€‹(i)subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ‘–T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}T_{\varepsilon}(i). The speedup in comparison with a no-collaboration strategy (all agents locally performing SGD) is 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}: the mean of all all-for-one speed-ups. Similarly in SettingÂ 2, the speed-up in comparison with the no-collaboration setting is still 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)} in the statistical regime. In SettingÂ 2, one could obtain Îºğœ…\sqrt{\kappa} instead of Îºğœ…\kappa in the optimization term, using accelerated gradient methods (with additive noise here), leading to a faster convergence to the statistical regime (first term of the max in TheoremÂ 4.2), where we have the collaboration speedup. We present in AppendixÂ E.3 a time-adaptive variant with varying step sizes and matrices, that share the same sample complexity, and TheoremÂ 8 in AppendixÂ E.4 is the case Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0.

AssumptionÂ (B.1). Importantly, controlling the mean of local generalization errors leads to a much weaker bias assumption: instead of requiring a uniform control of gradient norms (as is done in all previous works, and in our all-for-one setting), our all-for-all algorithm only requires that for some (biâ€‹j)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—(b_{ij}), we have fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant b_{ij}: in the GEM setting e.g., even when gradients of fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} and fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} may differ a lot, if agent jğ‘—jâ€™s optimal model generalizes well-enough under agent iğ‘–iâ€™s distribution, they should collaborate. We believe this notion of function proximity that we leverage in this setting to be the weakest possible.

Intuition behind the algorithm. Perhaps surprisingly, matrix Wğ‘ŠW is in general not a gossip matrix (i.e.Â such that Wâ€‹ğŸ™=ğŸ™ğ‘Š11W\mathds{1}=\mathds{1}): agent iğ‘–i does not aggregate a convex combination of stochastic gradients, but a combination with scalars that do not necessarily sum to 1. In the collaborative GEM setting, we thus cannot say that the all-for-all algorithm acts as if, in parallel, each agent iğ‘–i trains a model on the mixture of distributions ğ’Ÿjsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—\mathcal{D}_{j} with weights Wiâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘—W_{ij}. In fact, as the analysis shows below, agent iğ‘–i trains a model on the mixture of distributions, with weights Î»iâ€‹jsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—\lambda_{ij}, if Î›Î›\Lambda is a stochastic square root of matrix Wğ‘ŠW (Î›â€‹Î›âŠ¤=WÎ›superscriptÎ›topğ‘Š\Lambda\Lambda^{\top}=W). Thus, the all-for-all algorithm is exactly a paralleled version of weighted gradient averagings, where agent iğ‘–i uses the stochastic vector (Î»iâ€‹j)1â©½jâ©½Nsubscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘—ğ‘(\lambda_{ij})_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}. In order to account for inter-dependencies between agents that do not directly share information, the all-for-all gradient filtering uses weights Wiâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘—W_{ij} to aggregate information, instead of Î»iâ€‹jsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—\lambda_{ij}. Propagating information using a matrix Wğ‘ŠW, that induces a similarity graph GWsubscriptğºğ‘ŠG_{W} on {1,â€¦,N}1â€¦ğ‘{{\left\{1,\ldots,N\right\}}}, such that (iâ€‹j)âˆˆEWğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ¸ğ‘Š(ij)\in E_{W} if Wiâ€‹j>0subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘—0W_{ij}>0, is quite naturalÂ (Vanhaesebrouck etÂ al., 2017; Bellet etÂ al., 2018); yet, ours is the first analysis to give such precise generalization error bounds, through the use of a stochastic optimization framework.

Degrees of freedom offered by Wğ‘ŠW. In comparison to TheoremÂ 3, the classical personalized FL approaches that consider personalized local models of the form xi=xÂ¯âˆ’Î´isubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Â¯ğ‘¥subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–x_{i}=\bar{x}-\delta_{i}, where xÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¥\bar{x} is some global quantity shared by all agents, perturbed (and personalized) by some local quantity Î´isubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\delta_{i} (e.g.Â averaging between local and a global models), can be seen as the special instances where, for all iğ‘–i, we have Î»iâ€‹i=1âˆ’Î±isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘–1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\lambda_{ii}=1-\alpha_{i} and Î»iâ€‹j=Î±iNâˆ’1subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘1\lambda_{ij}=\frac{\alpha_{i}}{N-1} if iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq j for some Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\alpha_{i}, and leads to bias terms of the form 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘iÎ±iNâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘jâ‰ ibiâ€‹j1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘1subscriptğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}\frac{\alpha_{i}}{N-1}\sum_{j\neq i}b_{ij}. Full and naive collaboration (a single model trained for all users) corresponds to Î»iâ€‹j=1/Nsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘\lambda_{ij}=1/N for all i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,j, and leads to a bias term of 1N2â€‹âˆ‘i,jbiâ€‹j1superscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\frac{1}{N^{2}}\sum_{i,j}b_{ij}. The degrees of freedom offered by our matrix Wğ‘ŠW (and by coefficients Î»iâ€‹jsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—\lambda_{ij}) enable pairwise agent adaptation, and tighter generalization guarantees and bias/variance tradeoffs.

Proof sketch of convergence guarantees.

Since brutally analyzing convergence of the iterates (xk)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜(x^{k}) generated with xk+1=xkâˆ’Wâ€‹Gksuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘Šsuperscriptğºğ‘˜x^{k+1}=x^{k}-WG^{k} seems impossible due to both gradient biases and model biases between agents, we study these iterates through the introduction of a different but related problem. This approach is in fact similar to some decentralized optimization ones, where a dual problem or a related energy function is often introduced (Scaman etÂ al., 2019; Even etÂ al., 2021), upon which well-studied algorithms are applied. The related problem we formulate is different from and more flexible than all the different personalized FL problems in the literature (Hanzely etÂ al., 2020; T.Â Dinh etÂ al., 2020), that consider regularization terms that enforce consensus. For Î»=(Î»iâ€‹j)1â©½i,jâ©½Nğœ†subscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—formulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘\lambda=(\lambda_{ij})_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N} a stochastic matrix (such that for all 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, we have âˆ‘j=1NÎ»iâ€‹j=1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—1\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{ij}=1), let fÎ›superscriptğ‘“Î›f^{\Lambda} be defined as:

fÎ›â€‹(y)=fÂ¯â€‹(Î›â€‹y),yâˆˆâ„NÃ—d,formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘“Î›ğ‘¦Â¯ğ‘“Î›ğ‘¦ğ‘¦superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘‘f^{\Lambda}(y)=\bar{f}(\Lambda y)\,,\quad y\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d}\,, (8)

where fÂ¯=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘ifiÂ¯ğ‘“1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\bar{f}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}f_{i}. Gradient descent on fÎ›superscriptğ‘“Î›f^{\Lambda} writes as

yk+1=ykâˆ’Î·â€‹Î›âŠ¤â€‹âˆ‡fÂ¯â€‹(Î›â€‹yk)superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğœ‚superscriptÎ›topâˆ‡Â¯ğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y^{k+1}=y^{k}-\eta\Lambda^{\top}\nabla\bar{f}(\Lambda y^{k})\,

where âˆ‡fÂ¯â€‹(x)=1Nâ€‹(âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xi))1â©½iâ©½Nâˆ‡Â¯ğ‘“ğ‘¥1ğ‘subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘\nabla\bar{f}(x)=\frac{1}{N}\big{(}\nabla f_{i}(x_{i})\big{)}_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N} for any xâˆˆâ„NÃ—dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times d}. Importantly, notice that denoting xk=Î›â€‹yksuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜x^{k}=\Lambda y^{k} and since W=Î›â€‹Î›âŠ¤ğ‘ŠÎ›superscriptÎ›topW=\Lambda\Lambda^{\top}, we have the recursion

xk+1=xkâˆ’Î·â€‹Wâ€‹âˆ‡fÂ¯â€‹(xk)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğœ‚ğ‘Šâˆ‡Â¯ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\eta W\nabla\bar{f}(x^{k})\,

making an analysis of the iterates (xk)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜(x^{k}) possible. In our case, we however use stochastic gradients given by our oracles. The full gradient âˆ‡fÂ¯â€‹(x)âˆ‡Â¯ğ‘“ğ‘¥\nabla\bar{f}(x) is thus replaced by (Gkâ€‹(xi)i)isubscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘˜subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–(G^{k}(x_{i})_{i})_{i} defined at EquationÂ (7). Defining (yk)ksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğ‘˜(y^{k})_{k} with the recursion:

yk+1=ykâˆ’Î·((Î›Gk(yk)i)i,y^{k+1}=y_{k}-\eta((\Lambda G^{k}(y^{k})_{i})_{i}\,,

initialized at y10=x10=â€¦=yN0=xN0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦01subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥01â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¦0ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘y^{0}_{1}=x^{0}_{1}=\ldots=y^{0}_{N}=x^{0}_{N} we have xk=Î›â€‹yksuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜x^{k}=\Lambda y^{k}, for all kâ©¾0ğ‘˜0k\geqslant 0, where (xk)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜(x^{k}) is generated using AlgorithmÂ 1. As a consequence, controlling in TheoremÂ 3 the function values 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘ifiâ€‹(xik)1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}f_{i}(x_{i}^{k}) is equivalent to controlling fÎ›â€‹(yk)superscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜f^{\Lambda}(y^{k}) (these two quantities are equal). The bias-variance trade-off thus writes as, where xÎ›superscriptğ‘¥Î›x^{\Lambda} minimizes fÎ›superscriptğ‘“Î›f^{\Lambda} and xâ‹†=(xiâ‹†)1â©½iâ©½Nsuperscriptğ‘¥â‹†subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†1ğ‘–ğ‘x^{\star}=(x_{i}^{\star})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N}:

Fkâ©½fÎ›â€‹(xÎ›)âˆ’fÂ¯â€‹(xâ‹†)âŸBias term+fÎ›â€‹(yk)âˆ’fÎ›â€‹(xÎ›)âŸOptimization and variance terms.superscriptğ¹ğ‘˜subscriptâŸsuperscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¥Î›Â¯ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†Bias termsubscriptâŸsuperscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¥Î›Optimization and variance termsF^{k}\leqslant\underbrace{f^{\Lambda}(x^{\Lambda})-\bar{f}(x^{\star})}_{\text{\emph{Bias term}}}+\underbrace{f^{\Lambda}(y^{k})-f^{\Lambda}(x^{\Lambda})}_{\text{\emph{Optimization and variance terms}}}\,.

âˆ

6. Collaborative GEM

In this section, we place ourselves in the GEM setting (loss function â„“â„“\ell, distributions (ğ’Ÿi)isubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘–(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{i}). We briefly elaborate (see AppendixÂ A for further details) on the collaborative GEM setting we used through the paper, clearly define the distribution-based distances related to bias assumptionsÂ (B.1) andÂ (B.3), and introduce toy problems under which the bias upperbounds may be known.

6.1. Distribution-based distances.

For â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} a set of functions from ÎÎ\Xi to â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} and ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime} two probability distributions on ÎÎ\Xi, we define:

dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²)=suphâˆˆâ„‹â€–ğ”¼â€‹[hâ€‹(Î¾)âˆ’hâ€‹(Î¾â€²)]â€–,subscriptğ‘‘â„‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²subscriptsupremumâ„â„‹normğ”¼delimited-[]â„ğœ‰â„superscriptğœ‰â€²d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=\sup_{h\in\mathcal{H}}{{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[h(\xi)-h(\xi^{\prime})\right]\right\|}}\,,

where Î¾âˆ¼ğ’Ÿsimilar-toğœ‰ğ’Ÿ\xi\sim\mathcal{D} and Î¾â€²âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâ€²similar-tosuperscriptğœ‰â€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\xi^{\prime}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime}. dâ„‹subscriptğ‘‘â„‹d_{\mathcal{H}} is a pseudo-distance on the set of probability measures on ÎÎ\Xi. The definition of dâ„‹subscriptğ‘‘â„‹d_{\mathcal{H}} is motivated by the fact that, for fixed xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in\mathcal{X} and 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, we have:

â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fjâ€‹(x)â€–â©½dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj),normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\right\|}}\leqslant d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\,,

if (Î¾âˆˆÎâ†¦âˆ‡xâ„“â€‹(x,Î¾))âˆˆâ„‹ğœ‰Îmaps-tosubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰â„‹\big{(}\xi\in\Xi\mapsto\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi)\big{)}\in\mathcal{H} where (Î¾i,Î¾j)âˆ¼ğ’ŸiÃ—ğ’Ÿjsimilar-tosubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptğœ‰ğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—(\xi_{i},\xi_{j})\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}\times\mathcal{D}_{j}. Thus, if for all 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½b^iâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant\hat{b}_{ij} for some weights b^iâ€‹jsubscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\hat{b}_{ij}, bias assumptionÂ (B.1) holds for biâ€‹j=supk,lâ€–xkâ‹†âˆ’xlâ‹†â€–â€‹b^iâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptsupremumğ‘˜ğ‘™normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™â‹†subscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—b_{ij}=\sup_{k,l}{{\left\|x_{k}^{\star}-x_{l}^{\star}\right\|}}\hat{b}_{ij} (and for b^iâ€‹j2/(2â€‹Î¼)superscriptsubscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—22ğœ‡\hat{b}_{ij}^{2}/(2\mu) under Î¼ğœ‡\mu-PL assumption), and bias assumptionÂ (B.2) holds for b~iâ€‹j=b^iâ€‹j2subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—2\tilde{b}_{ij}=\hat{b}_{ij}^{2}.

6.2. Weakly supervised setting.

In a scenario where, from a large pool of unlabelled data (distributions (ğ’Ÿ^i)isubscriptsubscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘–(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{i})_{i}), requiring a label led to a sample from ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} but were costly, agents would benefit from computing distance-based distributions between unlabelled distributions (ğ’Ÿ^i)isubscriptsubscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘–(\hat{\mathcal{D}}_{i})_{i} (possible thanks to a large amount of unlabelled samples); these computed distances would then help to reduce the number of labelled samples required.

6.3. Geometric structure of the agents and infinitely-many-agents.

A toy problem is to assume that agent distributions are drawn in an i.i.d.Â fashion from a continuous set of possible distributions Î˜âŠ‚â„pÎ˜superscriptâ„ğ‘\Theta\subset\mathbb{R}^{p}: Î¸1,â€¦,Î¸Nâˆ¼Î½similar-tosubscriptğœƒ1â€¦subscriptğœƒğ‘ğœˆ\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{N}\sim\nu where Î½ğœˆ\nu is a density over the set Î˜Î˜\Theta. Making Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty, we end up with a continuum of agents of distributions (ğ’ŸÎ¸)Î¸âˆˆÎ˜subscriptsubscriptğ’ŸğœƒğœƒÎ˜(\mathcal{D}_{\theta})_{\theta\in\Theta} with density Î½ğœˆ\nu. In that setting, under a bias assumption of the form dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’ŸÎ¸,ğ’ŸÎ¸â€²)â©½b^â€‹(Î¸,Î¸â€²)â©½â€–Î¸âˆ’Î¸â€²â€–qsubscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğœƒsubscriptğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœƒâ€²^ğ‘ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²superscriptnormğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²ğ‘d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{\theta},\mathcal{D}_{\theta^{\prime}})\leqslant\hat{b}(\theta,\theta^{\prime})\leqslant{{\left\|\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right\|}}^{q} for all Î¸,Î¸â€²ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²\theta,\theta^{\prime}, the collaboration speedup of TheoremÂ 4.1 (for instance), writes as:

âˆ«Î˜(fÎ¸â€‹(xÎ¸)âˆ’fÎ¸â€‹(xÎ¸â‹†))â€‹Î½â€‹(dâ€‹Î¸)â©½Îµ,subscriptÎ˜subscriptğ‘“ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğœƒsubscriptğ‘“ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğœƒâ‹†ğœˆdğœƒğœ€\int_{\Theta}\big{(}f_{\theta}(x_{\theta})-f_{\theta}(x_{\theta}^{\star})\big{)}\nu({\rm d}\theta)\leqslant\varepsilon\,,

with a total number of samples drawn of

TÎµâ©½ğ’ªÎµâ†’0â€‹(B2â€‹D2â€‹Îµâˆ’2âˆ’p/q),subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€subscriptğ’ªâ†’ğœ€0superscriptğµ2superscriptğ·2superscriptğœ€2ğ‘ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\mathcal{O}_{\varepsilon\to 0}\left(B^{2}D^{2}\varepsilon^{-2-p/q}\right)\,,

under regularity assumptions on Î½ğœˆ\nu and b^^ğ‘\hat{b}. This approach is made more rigorous in AppendixÂ A.4.

6.4. Illustration of our theory.

To test the robustness of our algorithms and our theory, we use in our experiments the mean estimation problem used in the strongly convex and smooth lower bound of TheoremÂ 1: â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)=12â€‹â€–xâˆ’Î¾â€–2â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰12superscriptnormğ‘¥ğœ‰2\ell(x,\xi)=\frac{1}{2}{{\left\|x-\xi\right\|}}^{2}, xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for Î¾ğœ‰\xi a dğ‘‘d-dimensional Bernoulli random variable. We use the time-adaptive version of AlgorithmÂ 1, and we place ourselves in the setting of SectionÂ A.4, where agent distributions are drawn from a distribution of distributions: for N=100ğ‘100N=100 agents, we draw (pi)1â©½iâ©½Nsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘(p_{i})_{1\leqslant i\leqslant N} i.i.d.Â uniformly distributed in [0,1]01[0,1], and pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} is the parameter of agent iğ‘–iâ€™s Bernoulli variables. We draw 103superscript10310^{3} samples for each agent, and we compute for 1â©½tâ©½T1ğ‘¡ğ‘‡1\leqslant t\leqslant T the averaged local generalization errors (here the error from the mean), namely 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1N12â€‹â€–xitâˆ’piâ€–21ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘12superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{2}{{\left\|x_{i}^{t}-p_{i}\right\|}}^{2}, where xitsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡x_{i}^{t} is the output of the algorithm after tğ‘¡t samples drawn. As expected and as illustrated in FigureÂ 1(a), our all-for-all approach benefits from both no-collaboration (each agent locally estimating its mean pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} with only its locally available samples, in orange in the graph) and single-model approaches (a fully centralized minimization of 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘ifiâ€‹(x)1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}f_{i}(x), in green in the graph), through both a convergence to the true mean, and a non-asymptotic acceleration. In FigureÂ 1(b), we study the effect of noise on the estimation of bias parameters biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—b_{ij} (that here correspond to biâ€‹j=12â€‹(piâˆ’pj)2subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—12superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—2b_{ij}=\frac{1}{2}(p_{i}-p_{j})^{2}), by taking as inputs in algorithms biâ€‹jnoisy=12â€‹(pi+niâˆ’pjâˆ’nj)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—noisy12superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘›ğ‘—2b_{ij}^{\rm noisy}=\frac{1}{2}(p_{i}+n_{i}-p_{j}-n_{j})^{2}, where nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i} are i.i.d.Â uniformly distributed in [âˆ’noise,noise]noisenoise[-{\rm noise},{\rm noise}], for different noise values (FigureÂ 1(b)). All-for-all algorithm appears to be quite robust to noise: for small noise amplitudes (0.02 and 0.08, and even 0.18), performances are not too degraded. For (abusively) large noise values (0.32 and 0.5), the non-asymptotic speedup is kept, with degraded asymptotic performances. Still, in the range of parameters considered, these perform better than no-collaboration and single model approaches.

Discussion and conclusion.

In this paper, we quantified in term of function biases (biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—b_{ij}), stochastic gradient noise or amplitudes (Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} or B2superscriptğµ2B^{2}), target precision Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 and functions regularity parameters, the benefit of collaboration between agents for shared minimization using stochastic gradient algorithms. Our lower bound (TheoremÂ 1) states that in theÂ all-for-one setting, assumption parameters being fixed, no algorithm matches the performances of weighted gradient averagings in terms of sample optimality. Another lower bound (and corresponding upper-bounds) that would be worth investigating is: without any knowledge on biases biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—b_{ij}, what is the worst case complexity of an algorithm that would thus need to learn who to learn with? We extended weighted gradient averagings to the all-for-all setting, technically more challenging, through the introduction of a related problem, simplifying the analysis of such algorithms.

The main limitation of our work lies in the assumption that upper-bounds on the biases biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—b_{ij} are known. We investigate in SectionÂ A scenarii in which this assumption is valid. Yet, as mentionned above, learning who to learn with and how is a challenging question worth tackling. Extending our work to model agnosticism together with data heterogeneity would require bias assumptions such as our distribution-based ones in SectionÂ A. Finally, fairness issues might be raised by our approaches in the all-for-all setting: we consider the average errors amongst agents and therefore do not ensure bounds on the supremum of all local errors. Still, incentives to collaborate and send gradients to other users are the hope of being helped back (matrix Wğ‘ŠW is symmetric in AlgorithmÂ 1).

  • Yu etÂ al. (2021) Tao Yu, Eugene Bagdasaryan, and Vitaly Shmatikov. Salvaging Federated Learning by Local Adaptation. arXiv:2002.04758 [cs, stat], October 2021. arXiv: 2002.04758.
  • Zhang etÂ al. (2013) Yuchen Zhang, John Duchi, MichaelÂ I Jordan, and MartinÂ J Wainwright. Information-theoretic lower bounds for distributed statistical estimation with communication constraints. In C.Â J.Â C. Burges, L.Â Bottou, M.Â Welling, Z.Â Ghahramani, and K.Â Q. Weinberger, editors, Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, volumeÂ 26. Curran Associates, Inc., 2013.

Appendix A The Case of Collaborative Generalization Error Minimization (GEM)

In most of the related works and in this paper, the quantities equivalent to our bias assumptions are assumed to be known by the optimizer. Yet, while this assumption makes analyses possible, the knowledge of these quantities is a strong assumption. In this section, we provide settings and toy problems under which these assumptions are natural. We first begin by introducing distribution based distances between agents, in order to control gradient biases in the setting where functions are of the formÂ (5) for a shared loss â„“â„“\ell and local distributions (ğ’Ÿi)isubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘–(\mathcal{D}_{i})_{i}, for collaborative GEM. We then present two settings for this problem.

A.1. Distribution-based distances

In order to quantify the bias/variance tradeoff that appears when using stochastic gradients computed by other agents, we define the following notion of distance.

Definition 1.

For â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} a set of functions from ÎÎ\Xi to â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} and ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime} two probability distributions on ÎÎ\Xi, we define:

dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²)=suphâˆˆâ„‹â€–ğ”¼â€‹[hâ€‹(Î¾)âˆ’hâ€‹(Î¾â€²)]â€–,subscriptğ‘‘â„‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²subscriptsupremumâ„â„‹normğ”¼delimited-[]â„ğœ‰â„superscriptğœ‰â€²d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=\sup_{h\in\mathcal{H}}{{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[h(\xi)-h(\xi^{\prime})\right]\right\|}}\,,

where Î¾âˆ¼ğ’Ÿsimilar-toğœ‰ğ’Ÿ\xi\sim\mathcal{D} and Î¾â€²âˆ¼ğ’Ÿâ€²similar-tosuperscriptğœ‰â€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\xi^{\prime}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime}. dâ„‹subscriptğ‘‘â„‹d_{\mathcal{H}} is a pseudo-distance on the set of probability measures on ÎÎ\Xi.

Some instances of these distances encompass:

  1. (1)

    For â„‹=â„‹Affineâ„‹subscriptâ„‹Affine\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{H}_{\rm Affine} the set of 1-Lipschitz affine functions, we have dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²)=â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î¾]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î¾â€²]â€–subscriptğ‘‘â„‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²normğ”¼delimited-[]ğœ‰ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğœ‰â€²d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})={{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\xi\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\xi^{\prime}\right]\right\|}}.

  2. (2)

    For â„‹=â„‹Lipschitzâ„‹subscriptâ„‹Lipschitz\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{H}_{\rm Lipschitz} the set of 1-Lipschitz functions on ÎÎ\Xi, we have dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²)=ğ’²1â€‹(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘â„‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²subscriptğ’²1ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=\mathcal{W}_{1}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}) the 1-Wasserstein distance (or EMD, earth mover distance).

  3. (3)

    For â„‹=â„‹Boundedâ„‹subscriptâ„‹Bounded\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{H}_{\rm Bounded} the set of of functions whose values lie in a space of diameter 1, we have dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²)=dTVâ€‹(ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²)subscriptğ‘‘â„‹ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²subscriptğ‘‘TVğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime})=d_{\rm TV}(\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}) the total variation distance.

  4. (4)

    For â„‹=â„‹Loc.Boundedâ„‹subscriptâ„‹formulae-sequenceLocBounded\mathcal{H}=\mathcal{H}_{\rm Loc.Bounded} defined as {h:Îâ†’â„ds.t.âˆ€Î¾âˆˆÎ,Diamâ€‹(hâ€‹(â„¬â€‹(Î¾,1)âˆ©Î))â©½1}conditional-setâ„formulae-sequenceâ†’Îsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘s.t.formulae-sequencefor-allğœ‰ÎDiamâ„â„¬ğœ‰1Î1{{\left\{h:\Xi\to\mathbb{R}^{d}\quad\text{s.t.}\quad\forall\xi\in\Xi,\,{\rm Diam}\big{(}h(\mathcal{B}(\xi,1)\cap\Xi)\big{)}\leqslant 1\right\}}}, we also obtain the total variation distance.

The definition of dâ„‹subscriptğ‘‘â„‹d_{\mathcal{H}} is motivated by the fact that, for fixed xâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¥ğ’³x\in\mathcal{X} and 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, we have:

â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fjâ€‹(x)â€–normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥\displaystyle{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\right\|}} =â€–ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡xâ„“â€‹(x,Î¾i)âˆ’âˆ‡xâ„“â€‹(x,Î¾j)]â€–absentnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥â„“ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥â„“ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‰ğ‘—\displaystyle={{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi_{i})-\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi_{j})\right]\right\|}}
â©½dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj).absentsubscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—\displaystyle\leqslant d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\,.

if (Î¾âˆˆÎâ†¦âˆ‡xâ„“â€‹(x,Î¾))âˆˆâ„‹ğœ‰Îmaps-tosubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰â„‹\big{(}\xi\in\Xi\mapsto\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi)\big{)}\in\mathcal{H} where (Î¾i,Î¾j)âˆ¼ğ’ŸiÃ—ğ’Ÿjsimilar-tosubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptğœ‰ğ‘—subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—(\xi_{i},\xi_{j})\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}\times\mathcal{D}_{j}.

We thus add a fourth bias assumptions to our list in SectionÂ 2, called distribution-based bias assumption: for some function set â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}, for all 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½b^iâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant\hat{b}_{ij} for some non negative weights b^^ğ‘\hat{b}, and for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, (Î¾âˆˆÎâ†¦âˆ‡xâ„“â€‹(x,Î¾))âˆˆâ„‹ğœ‰Îmaps-tosubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰â„‹\big{(}\xi\in\Xi\mapsto\nabla_{x}\ell(x,\xi)\big{)}\in\mathcal{H}. This assumptions is verified in the following settings for mean estimation and regression.

  1. (1)

    For â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)=12â€‹(xâˆ’Î¾)2â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰12superscriptğ‘¥ğœ‰2\ell(x,\xi)=\frac{1}{2}(x-\xi)^{2} (mean estimation), distribution-based bias assumption holds for â„‹Affinesubscriptâ„‹Affine\mathcal{H}_{\rm Affine}, and the distance to consider is thus â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î¾i]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î¾j]â€–normğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğœ‰ğ‘—{{\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{i}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{j}\right]\right\|}}.

  2. (2)

    For quadratic loss (linear regression) â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)=12â€‹(aâŠ¤â€‹xâˆ’b)2â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰12superscriptsuperscriptğ‘topğ‘¥ğ‘2\ell(x,\xi)=\frac{1}{2}(a^{\top}x-b)^{2} where Î¾=(aâ€‹aâŠ¤,bâ€‹aâŠ¤)ğœ‰ğ‘superscriptğ‘topğ‘superscriptğ‘top\xi=(aa^{\top},ba^{\top}), we have â„‹=Dâ€‹â„‹Affineâ„‹ğ·subscriptâ„‹Affine\mathcal{H}=D\mathcal{H}_{\rm Affine}, where Dğ·D is the diameter of the space in which are iterates lie, and the distance to consider is thus a scaled 1-Wassertein distance between distributions

  3. (3)

    For logisic regression â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)=logâ¡(1+eâˆ’bâ€‹aâŠ¤â€‹x)â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰1superscriptğ‘’ğ‘superscriptğ‘topğ‘¥\ell(x,\xi)=\log(1+e^{-ba^{\top}x}) where Î¾=bâ€‹aâŠ¤ğœ‰ğ‘superscriptğ‘top\xi=ba^{\top}, we have â„‹=(1+1e)â€‹â„‹Lipschitzâ„‹11ğ‘’subscriptâ„‹Lipschitz\mathcal{H}=(1+\frac{1}{e})\mathcal{H}_{\rm Lipschitz} and the distance to consider is thus the 1-Wassertein distance between distributions (scaled with a constant factor).

  4. (4)

    For the hinge loss â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)=maxâ¡(0,1âˆ’bâ€‹aâŠ¤â€‹x)â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰01ğ‘superscriptğ‘topğ‘¥\ell(x,\xi)=\max(0,1-ba^{\top}x), for Î¾=bâ€‹aâŠ¤ğœ‰ğ‘superscriptğ‘top\xi=ba^{\top} we have â„‹=Dâ€‹â„‹Boundedâ„‹ğ·subscriptâ„‹Bounded\mathcal{H}=D\mathcal{H}_{\rm Bounded} where Dğ·D is the diameter of the space in which are iterates lie, and the distance to consider between distributions is thus a scaled total variation distance.

Thus, instead of controlling uniform concentration bounds on the gradients (under the GEM assumption, this can be done using anisotropic uniform concentration bounds, e.g.Â Even and Massoulie [2021]), one can leverage our bias assumptions by controlling distribution-based distances.

Proposition 1.

If for all 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½b^iâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant\hat{b}_{ij} (i.e.Â distribution-based bias assumption holds), then:

  1. (1)

    Bias assumptionÂ (B.1) holds for biâ€‹j=Dâ‹†â€‹b^iâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ·â‹†subscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—b_{ij}=D^{\star}\hat{b}_{ij};

  2. (2)

    Bias assumptionÂ (B.2) holds for b~iâ€‹j=b^iâ€‹j2subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscript^ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—2\tilde{b}_{ij}=\hat{b}_{ij}^{2}.

A.2. Lower-bounds (TheoremÂ 1) in term of distribution based distances

TheoremÂ 1 being formulated as IT-lower bounds for collaborative GEM, the distribution-based distances we introduced perfectly adapt to it. In fact, in the proof of the lower bounds, the distributions we build verify dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant b_{ij} if â„‹âŠ‚â„‹Lâ€‹oâ€‹c.Bâ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹nâ€‹dâ€‹eâ€‹dâ„‹subscriptâ„‹formulae-sequenceğ¿ğ‘œğ‘ğµğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘‘\mathcal{H}\subset\mathcal{H}_{Loc.Bounded}, so that the following directly holds.

Theorem 5.

Let Îµâˆˆ(0,1/16)ğœ€0116\varepsilon\in(0,1/16). Assume that the function set â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} satisfies:

â„‹AffineâŠ‚â„‹âŠ‚â„‹Lâ€‹oâ€‹c.Bâ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹nâ€‹dâ€‹eâ€‹d,subscriptâ„‹Affineâ„‹subscriptâ„‹formulae-sequenceğ¿ğ‘œğ‘ğµğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘‘\mathcal{H}_{\rm Affine}\subset\mathcal{H}\subset\mathcal{H}_{Loc.Bounded}\,,

and assume that either the synchronous or asynchronous oracle is used. Assume that (biâ€‹j)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—(b_{ij}) verifies the triangle inequality biâ€‹jâ©½biâ€‹k+bkâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—b_{ij}\leqslant b_{ik}+b_{kj} for all 1â©½i,j,kâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘1\leqslant i,j,k\leqslant N. Let ğ”»~â€‹(r,b,B)~ğ”»ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµ\tilde{\mathbb{D}}(r,b,B) be the set ğ”»â€‹(r,b,B)ğ”»ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµ\mathbb{D}(r,b,B), but where the bias assumptions are replaced by the distribution-based bias assumption (dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant b_{ij}), and similarly for ğ”»~Î¼=1/r2L=1/r2â€‹(r,b,Ïƒ)superscriptsubscript~ğ”»ğœ‡1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ¿1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğœ\tilde{\mathbb{D}}_{\mu=1/r^{2}}^{L=1/r^{2}}(r,b,\sigma).
