We have, for some constant C>0ğ¶0C>0 independent of the problem and any iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i\in\{1,\ldots,N\}:

infâ„³âˆˆğ•„sup((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“)âˆˆğ”»~â€‹(r,b,B)ğ’¯iÎµâ€‹(â„³,((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“))â©¾Câ€‹B2â€‹r2â€‹NÎµ2â€‹ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b4),subscriptinfimumâ„³ğ•„subscriptsupremumsubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“~ğ”»ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘–ğœ€â„³subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“ğ¶superscriptğµ2superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘4\inf_{\mathcal{M}\in\mathbb{M}}\!\sup_{((\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell)\in\tilde{\mathbb{D}}(r,b,B)}\!\!\!\!\!\!\mathcal{T}_{i}^{\varepsilon}\Big{(}\mathcal{M},\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell\big{)}\Big{)}\!\geqslant\!\frac{CB^{2}r^{2}N}{\varepsilon^{2}\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(\frac{b}{4})}\,,

where ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b)=âˆ‘jğŸ™{biâ€‹jâ©½Îµ}superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘subscriptğ‘—subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(b)=\sum_{j}\mathds{1}_{\{b_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon\}} is the number of agents jğ‘—j verifying biâ€‹jâ©½Îµsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€b_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon. Under strong-convexity and smoothness assumptions for Î¼=L=1/r2ğœ‡ğ¿1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2\mu=L=1/r^{2}, this bound becomes, for some constant Câ€²>0superscriptğ¶â€²0C^{\prime}>0:

infâ„³âˆˆğ•„sup((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“)âˆˆğ”»~Î¼=1/r2L=1/r2â€‹(r,b,Ïƒ)ğ’¯iÎµâ€‹(â„³,((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“))â©¾Câ€²â€‹r2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹NÎµâ€‹ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b4).subscriptinfimumâ„³ğ•„subscriptsupremumsubscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“superscriptsubscript~ğ”»ğœ‡1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ¿1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘–ğœ€â„³subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“superscriptğ¶â€²superscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptğœ2ğ‘ğœ€superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘4\inf_{\mathcal{M}\in\mathbb{M}}\!\sup_{((\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell)\in\tilde{\mathbb{D}}_{\mu=1/r^{2}}^{L=1/r^{2}}(r,b,\sigma)}\!\!\!\!\!\!\mathcal{T}_{i}^{\varepsilon}\Big{(}\mathcal{M},\big{(}(\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell\big{)}\Big{)}\geqslant\frac{C^{\prime}r^{2}\sigma^{2}N}{\varepsilon\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(\frac{b}{4})}\,.

A.3. Weak supervision

We explicit in this section another paradigm in which the knowledge of some distribution-based bias assumptions is realistic, in a weakly supervised learning setting. More precisely, assume that the desired task is a classification or regression one: random variables Î¾ğœ‰\xi are of the form Î¾=(Î¶,Î²)ğœ‰ğœğ›½\xi=(\zeta,\beta) for some Î¶âˆˆZâŠ‚â„D1ğœğ‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ·1\zeta\in Z\subset\mathbb{R}^{D_{1}} and some label Î²âˆˆâ„D2ğ›½superscriptâ„subscriptğ·2\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{D_{2}}. For every agent 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, let ğ’ŸiÎ¶superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğœ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta} be the Î¶ğœ\zeta-marginal of ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}. In our weakly supervised learning setting, we assume that there exists some (eventually random) function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} that maps unlabelled data Î¶ğœ\zeta to their labelled ones i.e.Â for some â„’:Zâ†’Î:â„’â†’ğ‘Î\mathcal{L}:Z\to\Xi, the random variable â„’â€‹(Î¶i)â„’subscriptğœğ‘–\mathcal{L}(\zeta_{i}) is of same law as Î¾iâˆ¼ğ’Ÿisimilar-tosubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\xi_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i} for Î¶iâˆ¼ğ’ŸiÎ¶similar-tosubscriptğœğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğœ\zeta_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta}. While many samples may be accessible and drawn from ğ’ŸiÎ¶superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğœ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta} for every agent 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, labelling data i.e.Â applying function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} in order to recover samples of law ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} is assumed to be costly. For instance, applying â„’â„’\mathcal{L} in medical data analysis could require the help form an expert (a radiologist, â€¦).

Agents would benefit from computing distances between distributions ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} using marginals ğ’ŸiÎ¶superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğœ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta}: under mild assumptions on the function â„’â„’\mathcal{L} (Lipschitzness with high probability, mainly), distances dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)subscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j}) are upperbounded by distances between ğ’ŸiÎ¶superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğœ\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\zeta} and ğ’ŸjÎ¶superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğœ\mathcal{D}_{j}^{\zeta}. Thus, in this setting, agents would benefit from collaborating: computing distribution-based distances would not require expert advices, while reducing the total number of expert calls required by reducing the number of samples needed to be drawn from each ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} through collaboration.

A.4. Infinitely-Many-Agents Limit and Geometrical Prior Knowledge

We introduce the infinitely-many-agents limit, by taking Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty with added structure on the problem below. This toy-problem illustrates a geometric structure under which the knowledge of distribution-based bias assumptions is realistic. Let ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} be a set of probability laws and Î˜âŠ‚â„pÎ˜superscriptâ„ğ‘\Theta\subset\mathbb{R}^{p} be a set parameterizing ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} in the sense that ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} can be written as {ğ’ŸÎ¸,Î¸âˆˆÎ˜}subscriptğ’ŸğœƒğœƒÎ˜\{\mathcal{D}_{\theta},\,\theta\in\Theta\} where ğ’ŸÎ¸,Î¸âˆˆÎ˜subscriptğ’ŸğœƒğœƒÎ˜\mathcal{D}_{\theta},\,\theta\in\Theta are probability laws on ÎÎ\Xi. For all 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, we assume that there exists Î¸1,â€¦,Î¸NâˆˆÎ˜subscriptğœƒ1â€¦subscriptğœƒğ‘Î˜\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{N}\in\Theta such that ğ’Ÿi=ğ’ŸÎ¸isubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğœƒğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}=\mathcal{D}_{\theta_{i}}, and that the agents are drawn from a probability distribution with density Î½ğœˆ\nu on Î˜Î˜\Theta: (Î¸i)isubscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘–(\theta_{i})_{i} is a sequence of i.i.d.Â vectors sampled from Î˜Î˜\Theta with density Î½ğœˆ\nu.

This aims at modelling a geometric structure on the agents distributions: agents iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j such that Î¸isubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta_{i} and Î¸jsubscriptğœƒğ‘—\theta_{j} are nearby in the set Î˜Î˜\Theta share similar distributions. We quantify this in the following way: there exists a continuous function b:Î˜2â†’â„+:ğ‘â†’superscriptÎ˜2superscriptâ„b:\Theta^{2}\to\mathbb{R}^{+} such that for any (Î¸,Î¸â€²)âˆˆÎ˜2ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²superscriptÎ˜2(\theta,\theta^{\prime})\in\Theta^{2}, dâ„‹â€‹(Î¸,Î¸â€²)â©½bâ€‹(Î¸,Î¸â€²)subscriptğ‘‘â„‹ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²ğ‘ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²d_{\mathcal{H}}(\theta,\theta^{\prime})\leqslant b(\theta,\theta^{\prime}). In sensor networks, Î˜Î˜\Theta is some domain of â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2} of â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}, each agent is a sensor located at a physical position in Î˜Î˜\Theta, whose goal is to predict based on noisy local observations (e.g.Â temperature, pollution,Â â€¦) that are space-continuous. More generally, if agents model a population (agent iğ‘–i being an individual in the population) in some geographical location Î˜âŠ‚ğ’®2Î˜subscriptğ’®2\Theta\subset\mathcal{S}_{2} (sphere in â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3}) (ranging from cities, countries, continents, or the whole wide world), and if we are interested in speech-recognition models, a fair assumption is to have similar local distributions for nearby agents. The distribution Î½ğœˆ\nu is then the geographical density of agents.

The infinitely-many-agents limit is obtained by taking Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty with our geometric structure on the agents: we obtain a continuum of agents parameterized by Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta, with density Î½ğœˆ\nu on Î˜Î˜\Theta. For every Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta, we write:

fÎ¸â€‹(x)=ğ”¼Î¾âˆ¼ğ’ŸÎ¸â€‹[â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)],xâˆˆğ’³,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘“ğœƒğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ‰subscriptğ’Ÿğœƒdelimited-[]â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰ğ‘¥ğ’³f_{\theta}(x)=\mathbb{E}_{\xi\sim\mathcal{D}_{\theta}}[\ell(x,\xi)]\,,\quad x\in\mathcal{X}\,,

and we denote by xÎ¸â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğœƒâ‹†x_{\theta}^{\star} a minimizer over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} of fÎ¸subscriptğ‘“ğœƒf_{\theta}. The algorithm and model we consider are defined as follows, inspired by Oracle 2.

Infinitely-many-agents oracle and algorithm At each time-step t=1,2,â€¦ğ‘¡12â€¦t=1,2,...: 1: An agent parameterized by Î¸tâˆ¼Î½similar-tosubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğœˆ\theta_{t}\sim\nu is â€˜awakenedâ€™, draws Î¾Î¸ttsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‰subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘¡\xi_{\theta_{t}}^{t} is drawn from data distribution ğ’ŸÎ¸tsubscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{\theta_{t}} and computes a stochastic gradient gt=âˆ‡xâ„“â€‹(yt,Î¾Î¸tt)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥â„“subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ‰subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘¡g_{t}=\nabla_{x}\ell(y_{t},\xi_{\theta_{t}}^{t}). 2: Agents Î¸âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒÎ˜\theta\in\Theta such that wâ€‹(Î¸,Î¸t)â©½sÎµğ‘¤ğœƒsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ ğœ€w(\theta,\theta_{t})\leqslant s_{\varepsilon} for some fixed sÎµsubscriptğ‘ ğœ€s_{\varepsilon} receive gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t}. 3: Upon reception of gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t}, agents may update their local estimates.

At finite time-horizon T>0ğ‘‡0T>0, only a finite number of agents may have â€˜awakenedâ€™ and drawn (at most) one sample from their local distribution; yet, we aim at obtaining upper-bounds on the local generalization errors for all agents. Applying our AFO and AFA algorithms, under aditional assumptions, yields the following bounds.

Proposition 2.

Assume that Î½ğœˆ\nu is continuous on Î˜Î˜\Theta, and that for all Î¸,Î¸â€²âˆˆÎ˜ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²Î˜\theta,\theta^{\prime}\in\Theta, we have bâ€‹(Î¸,Î¸â€²)â©½â€–Î¸âˆ’Î¸â€²â€–qğ‘ğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²superscriptnormğœƒsuperscriptğœƒâ€²ğ‘b(\theta,\theta^{\prime})\leqslant{{\left\|\theta-\theta^{\prime}\right\|}}^{q}. Assume that assumptionÂ N.1 holds and that iterates lie in a space of diameter Dğ·D.

  1. (1)

    All-for-one: let Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 and Î¸âˆˆintâ€‹Ağœƒintğ´\theta\in{\rm int}\ {A}. There exists a procedure such that TÎµâ€‹(Î¸)subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğœƒT_{\varepsilon}(\theta) the time needed to reach a precision Îµğœ€\varepsilon for agent Î¸ğœƒ\theta is upper-bounded by:

    TÎµâ€‹(Î¸)â©½ğ’ªÎµâ†’0â€‹(B2â€‹D2â€‹Î½â€‹(Î¸)â€‹Îµâˆ’2âˆ’p/q).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğœƒsubscriptğ’ªâ†’ğœ€0superscriptğµ2superscriptğ·2ğœˆğœƒsuperscriptğœ€2ğ‘ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}(\theta)\leqslant\mathcal{O}_{\varepsilon\to 0}\left(B^{2}D^{2}\nu(\theta)\varepsilon^{-2-p/q}\right)\,.
  2. (2)

    All-for-all: for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, there exists a procedure making TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} oracle calls and answering (xÎ¸)Î¸âˆˆğ’³Î˜subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğœƒğœƒsuperscriptğ’³Î˜(x_{\theta})_{\theta}\in\mathcal{X}^{\Theta} such that:

    âˆ«Î˜(fÎ¸â€‹(xÎ¸)âˆ’fÎ¸â€‹(xÎ¸â‹†))â€‹Î½â€‹(dâ€‹Î¸)â©½Îµ,subscriptÎ˜subscriptğ‘“ğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥ğœƒsubscriptğ‘“ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğœƒâ‹†ğœˆdğœƒğœ€\int_{\Theta}\big{(}f_{\theta}(x_{\theta})-f_{\theta}(x_{\theta}^{\star})\big{)}\nu({\rm d}\theta)\leqslant\varepsilon\,,

    with

    TÎµâ©½ğ’ªÎµâ†’0â€‹(B2â€‹D2â€‹Îµâˆ’2âˆ’p/q).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€subscriptğ’ªâ†’ğœ€0superscriptğµ2superscriptğ·2superscriptğœ€2ğ‘ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\mathcal{O}_{\varepsilon\to 0}\left(B^{2}D^{2}\varepsilon^{-2-p/q}\right)\,.
Proof.

For finite number of agents Nğ‘N, we have Î¸1,â€¦,Î¸Nsubscriptğœƒ1â€¦subscriptğœƒğ‘\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{N} drawn i.i.d. from Î½ğœˆ\nu. Using weighted gradient averagings and TheoremÂ 2.1, we have for agent iğ‘–i, and denoting Î¸=Î¸iğœƒsubscriptğœƒğ‘–\theta=\theta_{i}:

TÎµâ€‹(Î¸)â©½2â€‹B2â€‹D2â€‹Îµâˆ’2â€‹ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)N.subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğœƒ2superscriptğµ2superscriptğ·2superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}(\theta)\leqslant 2B^{2}D^{2}\varepsilon^{-2}\frac{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}{N}\,.

Here, ğ’©iÎµ(2b)â©½|{1â©½jâ©½N:âˆ¥Î¸âˆ’Î¸jâˆ¥â©½(Îµ/2)1/q}=âˆ‘j=1NğŸ™{â€–Î¸âˆ’Î¸jâ€–â©½(Îµ/2)1/q}\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)\leqslant|{{\left\{1\leqslant j\leqslant N\,:\,{{\left\|\theta-\theta_{j}\right\|}}\leqslant(\varepsilon/2)^{1/q}\right\}}}=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\mathds{1}_{{{\left\{{{\left\|\theta-\theta_{j}\right\|}}\leqslant(\varepsilon/2)^{1/q}\right\}}}}. Using the strong law of large number, we have almost surely, as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty:

ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)Nâ©½âˆ«â„¬â€‹(Î¸,(Îµ/2)1/q)Î½â€‹(z)â€‹dz+oâ€‹(1).superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘ğ‘subscriptâ„¬ğœƒsuperscriptğœ€21ğ‘ğœˆğ‘§differential-dğ‘§ğ‘œ1\frac{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}{N}\leqslant\int_{\mathcal{B}(\theta,(\varepsilon/2)^{1/q})}\nu(z){\rm d}z+o(1)\,.

Thus, for Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty:

TÎµâ€‹(Î¸)â©½2â€‹B2â€‹D2â€‹âˆ«â„¬â€‹(Î¸,(Îµ/2)1/q)Î½â€‹(z)â€‹dz.subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğœƒ2superscriptğµ2superscriptğ·2subscriptâ„¬ğœƒsuperscriptğœ€21ğ‘ğœˆğ‘§differential-dğ‘§T_{\varepsilon}(\theta)\leqslant 2B^{2}D^{2}\int_{\mathcal{B}(\theta,(\varepsilon/2)^{1/q})}\nu(z){\rm d}z\,.

Then, making Îµâ†’0â†’ğœ€0\varepsilon\to 0, we have âˆ«â„¬â€‹(Î¸,(Îµ/2)1/q)Î½â€‹(z)â€‹dzâˆ¼Îµâ†’0Î½â€‹(Î¸)â€‹Volâ€‹(â„¬â€‹(Î¸,(Îµ/2)1/q))=ğ’ªâ€‹(Î½â€‹(Î¸)â€‹Îµâˆ’p/q)subscriptsimilar-toâ†’ğœ€0subscriptâ„¬ğœƒsuperscriptğœ€21ğ‘ğœˆğ‘§differential-dğ‘§ğœˆğœƒVolâ„¬ğœƒsuperscriptğœ€21ğ‘ğ’ªğœˆğœƒsuperscriptğœ€ğ‘ğ‘\int_{\mathcal{B}(\theta,(\varepsilon/2)^{1/q})}\nu(z){\rm d}z\sim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\nu(\theta){\rm Vol}(\mathcal{B}(\theta,(\varepsilon/2)^{1/q}))=\mathcal{O}\left(\nu(\theta)\varepsilon^{-p/q}\right) (Î½ğœˆ\nu is continuous). We thus have the result for Î¸ğœƒ\theta such that Î½â€‹(Î¸)>0ğœˆğœƒ0\nu(\theta)>0 in the all-for-one setting.

In the all-for-all setting, we use TheoremÂ 4.1 in for a finite number of agents, and we similarly use the strong law of large numbers as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty. âˆ

Appendix B Proof of Lower-Bounds (TheoremÂ 1 and CorollaryÂ 1)

B.1. General framework to prove lower bounds

The idea is that, when optimizing a function fâ€‹(x)=ğ”¼â€‹[â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)]ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ”¼delimited-[]â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰f(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[\ell(x,\xi)\right] and finding a good approximation of a minimizer xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star}, we learn some information on the distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} over which samples are drawn. In order to prove lower bounds, we construct a loss function â„“â„“\ell, and distributions ğ’Ÿ1Î±,â€¦,ğ’ŸNÎ±superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ›¼â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ğ›¼\mathcal{D}_{1}^{\alpha},\ldots,\mathcal{D}_{N}^{\alpha}, where Î±ğ›¼\alpha is a random parameter. We argue that minimizing (in the all-for-all or all-for-one settings) the objective function up to a certain precision gives a good estimator (quantified) of the random seeds Î±ğ›¼\alpha. Then, using Fano inequality, we bound the efficiency of such an estimator in terms of number of oracle calls, obtaining a lower bound on the sample complexity. This approach is inspired byÂ Agarwal etÂ al. [2012], who prove IT-lower bounds for stochastic gradient descent. We adapt their proof technique to the personalized and multi-agent setting.

Constructing difficult loss functions

For any two functions f,g:â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“ğ‘”â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f,g:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}, we define the discrepancy measure Ïâ€‹(f,g)ğœŒğ‘“ğ‘”\rho(f,g) as:

Ïâ€‹(f,g)=infxâˆˆâ„d{fâ€‹(x)+gâ€‹(x)âˆ’fâ€‹(xfâˆ—)âˆ’gâ€‹(xfâˆ—)},ğœŒğ‘“ğ‘”subscriptinfimumğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘”superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘“\rho(f,g)=\inf_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\Big{\{}f(x)+g(x)-f(x_{f}^{*})-g(x_{f}^{*})\Big{\}}\,,

which is a pseudo metrics. Now, for a finite set ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V} of parameters, let ğ’¢â€‹(Î´)={gÎ±Î´,Î±âˆˆğ’±}ğ’¢ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼ğ›¿ğ›¼ğ’±\mathcal{G}(\delta)={{\left\{g_{\alpha}^{\delta}\,,\,\alpha\in\mathcal{V}\right\}}} be a set of functions indexed by ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V}, that depend on Î´ğ›¿\delta (fixed in the set). The dependency of each gÎ±âˆˆğ’¢â€‹(Î´)subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼ğ’¢ğ›¿g_{\alpha}\in\mathcal{G}(\delta) is left implicit in the following subsections. We define:

Ïˆâ€‹(Î´)=inff,gâˆˆğ’¢â€‹(Î´)Ïâ€‹(f,g).ğœ“ğ›¿subscriptinfimumğ‘“ğ‘”ğ’¢ğ›¿ğœŒğ‘“ğ‘”\psi(\delta)=\inf_{f,g\in\mathcal{G}(\delta)}\rho(f,g)\,.

Minimizing is Bernoulli parameters identification

The two following lemmas justify that optimizing a function gÎ±âˆˆğ’¢â€‹(Î´)subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼ğ’¢ğ›¿g_{\alpha}\in\mathcal{G}(\delta) to a precision of order Ïˆâ€‹(Î´)ğœ“ğ›¿\psi(\delta) is more difficult than estimating the parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

Lemma 1 (Agarwal etÂ al. [2012]).

For any xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, there can be at most one function gÎ±subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼g_{\alpha} in ğ’¢â€‹(Î´)ğ’¢ğ›¿\mathcal{G}(\delta) such that:

gÎ±â€‹(x)âˆ’infâ„dgÎ±<Ïˆâ€‹(Î´)3.subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼ğ‘¥subscriptinfimumsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼ğœ“ğ›¿3g_{\alpha}(x)-\inf_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}g_{\alpha}<\frac{\psi(\delta)}{3}\,.
Lemma 2 (Agarwal etÂ al. [2012]).

Assume that for some fixed but unknown Î±âˆˆğ’±ğ›¼ğ’±\alpha\in\mathcal{V} there exists a method â„³Tsubscriptâ„³ğ‘‡\mathcal{M}_{T} based on the data Ï•={X1,â€¦,XT}italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘‡\phi=\{X_{1},...,X_{T}\} that returns xTsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡x^{T} (function of Ï•italic-Ï•\phi) satisfying an error of:

ğ”¼â€‹[gÎ±â€‹(xT)âˆ’minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡gÎ±â€‹(x)]<Ïˆâ€‹(Î´)9,ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼ğ‘¥ğœ“ğ›¿9\mathbb{E}\left[g_{\alpha}(x^{T})-\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}g_{\alpha}(x)\right]<\frac{\psi(\delta)}{9}\,,

where the mean is taken over the randomness of both the oracle Î¦Î¦\Phi, the method â„³Tsubscriptâ„³ğ‘‡\mathcal{M}_{T} and Î±âˆˆğ’±ğ›¼ğ’±\alpha\in\mathcal{V} if random. Then, there exists a hypothesis test Î±^:Ï•â†’ğ’±:^ğ›¼â†’italic-Ï•ğ’±\hat{\alpha}:\phi\to\mathcal{V} such that:

maxÎ±âˆˆğ’±â¡â„™Ï•â€‹(Î±^â‰ Î±)â©½13.subscriptğ›¼ğ’±subscriptâ„™italic-Ï•^ğ›¼ğ›¼13\max_{\alpha\in\mathcal{V}}\mathbb{P}_{\phi}\big{(}\hat{\alpha}\neq\alpha\big{)}\leqslant\frac{1}{3}\,.

Suppose now that the parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha in the previous Lemma is chosen uniformly at random in ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V}. Let Î±^:Ï•â†’ğ’±:^ğ›¼â†’italic-Ï•ğ’±\hat{\alpha}:\phi\to\mathcal{V} be a hypothesis test estimating Î±ğ›¼\alpha. By Fano inequality [Cover and Thomas, 2005], we have:

â„™â€‹(Î±^â‰ Î±)â©¾1âˆ’Iâ€‹(Ï•,Î±)+lnâ¡(2)|ğ’±|,â„™^ğ›¼ğ›¼1ğ¼italic-Ï•ğ›¼2ğ’±\mathbb{P}\big{(}\hat{\alpha}\neq\alpha)\geqslant 1-\frac{I\big{(}\phi,\alpha\big{)}+\ln(2)}{|\mathcal{V}|}\,, (9)

where Iâ€‹(Ï•,Î±)ğ¼italic-Ï•ğ›¼I\big{(}\phi,\alpha\big{)} is the mutual information between Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and Î±ğ›¼\alpha, that we need to upper-bound. Combining Fano inequality with LemmasÂ 1 andÂ 2, fixing a target error Îµ=Ïˆâ€‹(Î´)ğœ€ğœ“ğ›¿\varepsilon=\psi(\delta), we obtain a lower bound on the sample complexity TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon}:

13â©¾â„™Ï•â€‹(Î±^â‰ Î±)â©¾1âˆ’Iâ€‹(Ï•TÎµ,Î±)+lnâ¡(2)|ğ’±|,13subscriptâ„™italic-Ï•^ğ›¼ğ›¼1ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ›¼2ğ’±\frac{1}{3}\geqslant\mathbb{P}_{\phi}\big{(}\hat{\alpha}\neq\alpha\big{)}\geqslant 1-\frac{I\big{(}\phi_{T_{\varepsilon}},\alpha\big{)}+\ln(2)}{|\mathcal{V}|}\,,

where Ï•TÎµsubscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€\phi_{T_{\varepsilon}} is the information contained in TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} oracle calls. If we have an equality of the form Iâ€‹(Ï•TÎµ,Î±)=TÎµâ€‹Iâ€‹(Ï•1,Î±)ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ›¼subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ï•1ğ›¼I\big{(}\phi_{T_{\varepsilon}},\alpha\big{)}=T_{\varepsilon}I\big{(}\phi_{1},\alpha\big{)}, this gives:

TÎµâ©¾23â€‹|ğ’±|âˆ’lnâ¡(2)Iâ€‹(Ï•1,Î±).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€23ğ’±2ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ï•1ğ›¼T_{\varepsilon}\geqslant\frac{\frac{2}{3}|\mathcal{V}|-\ln(2)}{I(\phi_{1},\alpha)}\,. (10)

Playing with the different parameters Î´,Î±,ğ’±ğ›¿ğ›¼ğ’±\delta,\alpha,\mathcal{V} gives lower bounds in our all-for-one settings. We refer the interested reader to Chapter 2 inÂ Cover and Thomas [2005] for Fano inequality and mutual information.

B.2. Applying this in the all-for-one setting, first part of TheoremÂ 1

We first prove the lower bounds in the case of the asynchronous oracle (one data item sampled from personal distribution at each iteration).

We define the loss â„“:â„dÃ—Î:â„“superscriptâ„ğ‘‘Î\ell:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\Xi where ÎâŠ‚â„dÎsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\Xi\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} and Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0:

âˆ€(x,Î¾)âˆˆğ’³Ã—Î,â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)=1dâ€‹âˆ‘i=1d[Î¾â€‹fi+â€‹(x)+(1âˆ’Î¾)â€‹fiâˆ’â€‹(x)âˆ’Î´â€‹xi],formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¥ğœ‰ğ’³Îâ„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘delimited-[]ğœ‰superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥1ğœ‰superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ›¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\forall(x,\xi)\in\mathcal{X}\times\Xi\,,\quad\ell(x,\xi)=\frac{1}{d}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\Big{[}\xi f_{i}^{+}(x)+(1-\xi)f_{i}^{-}(x)-\delta x_{i}\Big{]}\,,

where

fi+â€‹(x)=|xi+1/2|fiâˆ’â€‹(x)=|xiâˆ’1/2|.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–12superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–12f_{i}^{+}(x)=|x_{i}+1/2|\,\quad f_{i}^{-}(x)=|x_{i}-1/2|\,.

Now, for any Î±âˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}dğ›¼superscript11ğ‘‘\alpha\in\{-1,1\}^{d}, Î´âˆˆ[0,1/2]ğ›¿012\delta\in[0,1/2] being fixed, we define:

gÎ±â€‹(x)=1dâ€‹âˆ‘i=1d[(12+Î±iâ€‹Î´)â€‹fi+â€‹(x)+(12âˆ’Î±iâ€‹Î´)â€‹fiâˆ’â€‹(x)âˆ’Î´â€‹xi].subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼ğ‘¥1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘delimited-[]12subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥12subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ›¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–g_{\alpha}(x)=\frac{1}{d}\sum_{i=1}^{d}\Big{[}\big{(}\frac{1}{2}+\alpha_{i}\delta\big{)}f_{i}^{+}(x)+\big{(}\frac{1}{2}-\alpha_{i}\delta\big{)}f_{i}^{-}(x)-\delta x_{i}\Big{]}\,. (11)

For simplicity, assume that r2=dsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘‘r^{2}=d and B2=1superscriptğµ21B^{2}=1. Let Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0 a free parameter. Let ğ’±={Î±1,â€¦,Î±K}âŠ‚{âˆ’1,1}dğ’±superscriptğ›¼1â€¦superscriptğ›¼ğ¾superscript11ğ‘‘\mathcal{V}=\{\alpha^{1},\ldots,\alpha^{K}\}\subset\{-1,1\}^{d} be a subset of the hypercube such that for all kâ‰ lğ‘˜ğ‘™k\neq l,

12â€‹âˆ‘i=1d|Î±ikâˆ’Î±il|â©¾d4,12superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘‘4\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}|\alpha_{i}^{k}-\alpha_{i}^{l}|\geqslant\frac{d}{4}\,,

i.e.Â ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V} is a d/4ğ‘‘4d/4-packing of the hypercube. We assume that âˆ’ğŸ™1-\mathds{1} (dğ‘‘d-dimensional vector with âˆ’11-1 at all its entries) is not in ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V} and that for all Î±âˆˆğ’±ğ›¼ğ’±\alpha\in\mathcal{V}, 12â€‹âˆ‘i=1d|Î±i+1|â©¾d412superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–1ğ‘‘4\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i=1}^{d}|\alpha_{i}+1|\geqslant\frac{d}{4}. We know that we can set |ğ’±|â©¾(2/e)d/2ğ’±superscript2ğ‘’ğ‘‘2|\mathcal{V}|\geqslant(2/\sqrt{e})^{d/2}. Without loss of generality, we prove a lower bound in the case where the agent that desires to minimize its local function is indexed by 111. For any i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N, let ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} be the probability distribution on {0,1}dsuperscript01ğ‘‘\{0,1\}^{d} of the following random variable:

Berâ€‹(12+Î´iâ€‹Î±k)â€‹ÏµkwhereÎ´i=(Î´âˆ’biâ€‹1)+,Ber12subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘˜wheresubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–superscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1{\rm Ber}\big{(}\frac{1}{2}+\delta_{i}\alpha_{k}\big{)}\epsilon_{k}\quad\text{where}\quad\delta_{i}=(\delta-b_{i1})^{+}\,,\\

where s+=maxâ¡(0,s)superscriptğ‘ 0ğ‘ s^{+}=\max(0,s) for sâˆˆâ„ğ‘ â„s\in\mathbb{R}, kğ‘˜k is taken uniformly at random in {1,â€¦,d}1â€¦ğ‘‘\{1,\ldots,d\}, (Ïµk)subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘˜(\epsilon_{k}) is the canonical basis of â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}, and Bâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹(p)ğµğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘{Ber}(p) is a Bernoulli random variable, independent of kğ‘˜k.

The function f1â€‹(x)=ğ”¼â€‹[â„“â€‹(x,Î¾1)]subscriptğ‘“1ğ‘¥ğ”¼delimited-[]â„“ğ‘¥subscriptğœ‰1f_{1}(x)=\mathbb{E}\left[\ell(x,\xi_{1})\right] for Î¾1âˆ¼ğ’Ÿ1similar-tosubscriptğœ‰1subscriptğ’Ÿ1\xi_{1}\sim\mathcal{D}_{1} verifies f1=gÎ±subscriptğ‘“1subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼f_{1}=g_{\alpha} for gÎ±subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼g_{\alpha} defined inÂ (11). For our fixed Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0 and any Î±,Î²âˆˆğ’±ğ›¼ğ›½ğ’±\alpha,\beta\in\mathcal{V}, gÎ±subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼g_{\alpha} is minimized at xÎ±=âˆ’Î±/2superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›¼2x^{\alpha}=-\alpha/2 and we have:

gÎ±â€‹(xÎ±)=1dâ€‹âˆ‘k=1d1âˆ’Î´â€‹Î±k2.subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘‘1ğ›¿subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜2g_{\alpha}(x^{\alpha})=\frac{1}{d}\sum_{k=1}^{d}\frac{1-\delta\alpha_{k}}{2}\,.

The discrepancies thus write as:

Ïâ€‹(gÎ±,gÎ²)=Î´dâ€‹âˆ‘k=1d|Î±kâˆ’Î²k|,ğœŒsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼subscriptğ‘”ğ›½ğ›¿ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜\rho(g_{\alpha},g_{\beta})=\frac{\delta}{d}\sum_{k=1}^{d}|\alpha_{k}-\beta_{k}|\,,

so that Ïˆâ€‹(Î´)â©¾Î´/4ğœ“ğ›¿ğ›¿4\psi(\delta)\geqslant\delta/4. Each gÎ±subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼g_{\alpha} is minimized for xÎ±=âˆ’Î±/2âˆˆâ„¬âˆâ€‹(0,1/2)âŠ‚â„¬â€‹(0,d/2)âŠ‚â„¬â€‹(x0,r)superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›¼2subscriptâ„¬012â„¬0ğ‘‘2â„¬superscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘Ÿx^{\alpha}=-\alpha/2\in\mathcal{B}_{\infty}(0,1/2)\subset\mathcal{B}(0,\sqrt{d}/2)\subset\mathcal{B}(x^{0},r) for x0=0superscriptğ‘¥00x^{0}=0 (where â„¬âˆsubscriptâ„¬\mathcal{B}_{\infty} denotes a ball for the infinity norm): we are in the case r=dğ‘Ÿğ‘‘r=\sqrt{d}.

We now bound the quantities fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star}). For any i=1,â€¦,Nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘i=1,\ldots,N, we have xiâ‹†=xÎ±=âˆ’Î±/2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›¼2x_{i}^{\star}=x^{\alpha}=-\alpha/2 if Î´iâ©¾Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ›¿2\delta_{i}\geqslant\delta/2, and xiâ‹†=ğŸ™/2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†12x_{i}^{\star}=\mathds{1}/2 otherwise. For 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N, if both Î´iâ©¾Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ›¿2\delta_{i}\geqslant\delta/2 and Î´jâ©¾Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—ğ›¿2\delta_{j}\geqslant\delta/2, then xiâ‹†=xjâ‹†=xÎ±superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼x_{i}^{\star}=x_{j}^{\star}=x^{\alpha}, and fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)=0subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†0f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})=0. Similarly, if both Î´i<Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ›¿2\delta_{i}<\delta/2 and Î´j<Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—ğ›¿2\delta_{j}<\delta/2, xiâ‹†=xjâ‹†=ğŸ™/2superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†12x_{i}^{\star}=x_{j}^{\star}=\mathds{1}/2 and fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)=0subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†0f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})=0. If Î´iâ©¾Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ›¿2\delta_{i}\geqslant\delta/2 and Î´j<Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—ğ›¿2\delta_{j}<\delta/2, then

fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†\displaystyle f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star}) =fiâ€‹(ğŸ™/2)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xÎ±)absentsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–12subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼\displaystyle=f_{i}(\mathds{1}/2)-f_{i}(x^{\alpha})
=1dâ€‹âˆ‘k=1d|Î±kâˆ’1|2â€‹(2â€‹Î´iâˆ’Î´)absent1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜122subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ›¿\displaystyle=\frac{1}{d}\sum_{k=1}^{d}\frac{|\alpha_{k}-1|}{2}(2\delta_{i}-\delta)
â©½2â€‹Î´iâˆ’Î´absent2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ›¿\displaystyle\leqslant 2\delta_{i}-\delta
â©½2â€‹(Î´iâˆ’Î´j).absent2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—\displaystyle\leqslant 2(\delta_{i}-\delta_{j})\,.

Since Î´iâˆ’Î´jâ©½biâ€‹j/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—2\delta_{i}-\delta_{j}\leqslant b_{ij}/2 using 1-Lipschitzness of the positive value and the triangle inequality verified by the vector bğ‘b, we have fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant b_{ij}. If Î´i<Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ›¿2\delta_{i}<\delta/2 and Î´j>Î´/2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—ğ›¿2\delta_{j}>\delta/2, we similarly have fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½1dâ€‹âˆ‘k=1d|Î±kâˆ’1|2â€‹(Î´âˆ’2â€‹Î´i)â©½biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜12ğ›¿2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant\frac{1}{d}\sum_{k=1}^{d}\frac{|\alpha_{k}-1|}{2}(\delta-2\delta_{i})\leqslant b_{ij}.

Since the functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are differentiable at all points where xkâ‰ 1/2,âˆ’1/2subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1212x_{k}\neq 1/2,-1/2, bounding â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fjâ€‹(x)â€–2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥2{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\right\|}}^{2} at the points where fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} and fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} are differentiable is enough to haveÂ (B.2). For xk<âˆ’1/2subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜12x_{k}<-1/2, we have âˆ‡kfiâ€‹(x)=âˆ‡kfjâ€‹(x)=âˆ’1âˆ’Î´subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥1ğ›¿\nabla_{k}f_{i}(x)=\nabla_{k}f_{j}(x)=-1-\delta and âˆ‡kfiâ€‹(x)=âˆ‡kfjâ€‹(x)=1âˆ’Î´subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥1ğ›¿\nabla_{k}f_{i}(x)=\nabla_{k}f_{j}(x)=1-\delta for xk>1/2subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜12x_{k}>1/2. For âˆ’1/2<xk<1/212subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜12-1/2<x_{k}<1/2, we have âˆ‡kfiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡kfjâ€‹(x)âˆ’2â€‹(Î´iâˆ’Î´j)â€‹Î±ksubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\nabla_{k}f_{i}(x)-\nabla_{k}f_{j}(x)-2(\delta_{i}-\delta_{j})\alpha_{k}, so that â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fjâ€‹(x)â€–2â©½4â€‹(Î´iâˆ’Î´j)2â©½biâ€‹j2/dsuperscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥24superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—2ğ‘‘{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla f_{j}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\leqslant 4(\delta_{i}-\delta_{j})^{2}\leqslant b_{ij}^{2}/d at all points where fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} and fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} are differentiable. The gradients scale with rğ‘Ÿr, hence the dependency in rğ‘Ÿr (we recall that r2=dsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘‘r^{2}=d in our case).

The mutual information Iâ€‹(Ï•T,Î±)ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘‡ğ›¼I(\phi_{T},\alpha) writes as:

Iâ€‹(Ï•T,Î±)ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘‡ğ›¼\displaystyle I(\phi_{T},\alpha) =Tâ€‹Iâ€‹(Ï•1,Î±)absentğ‘‡ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ï•1ğ›¼\displaystyle=TI(\phi_{1},\alpha)
=Tdâ€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘k=1dâˆ‘i=1NIâ€‹(Berâ€‹(12+ğŸ™b1â€‹iâ©½Î´â€‹Î±kâ€‹Î´i),Î±k)absentğ‘‡ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ¼Ber12subscript1subscriptğ‘1ğ‘–ğ›¿subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\displaystyle=\frac{T}{dN}\sum_{k=1}^{d}\sum_{i=1}^{N}I\left({\rm Ber}\big{(}\frac{1}{2}+\mathds{1}_{b_{1i}\leqslant\delta}\alpha_{k}\delta_{i}\big{)},\alpha_{k}\right)
â©½C1â€‹TNâ€‹âˆ‘i=1NğŸ™b1â€‹i<Î´â€‹Î´i2absentsubscriptğ¶1ğ‘‡ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscript1subscriptğ‘1ğ‘–ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–2\displaystyle\leqslant\frac{C_{1}T}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathds{1}_{b_{1i}<\delta}\delta_{i}^{2}
=C1â€‹Tâ€‹ğ’©1Î´â€‹(b)Nâ€‹Î´2,absentsubscriptğ¶1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ’©1ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ›¿2\displaystyle=\frac{C_{1}T\mathcal{N}_{1}^{\delta}(b)}{N}\delta^{2}\,,

for some numerical constant C>0ğ¶0C>0 independent of the problem. Using EquationÂ (10) then leads to, for Îµ=Ïˆâ€‹(Î´)ğœ€ğœ“ğ›¿\varepsilon=\psi(\delta):

TÎµâ©¾Câ€‹dâ€‹NÎµ2â€‹ğ’©1Îµâ€‹(4â€‹b),subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ¶ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ’©1ğœ€4ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\geqslant C\frac{dN}{\varepsilon^{2}\mathcal{N}_{1}^{\varepsilon}(4b)}\,, (12)

where C>0ğ¶0C>0 is a numerical constant independent of the problem.

EquationÂ (12) is obtained for the choice of loss function and distributions defined above, and the functions defined are in ğ”»â€‹(r,b,B)ğ”»ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµ\mathbb{D}(r,b,B) for r=dğ‘Ÿğ‘‘r=\sqrt{d}, the fixed weights bğ‘b, and B2=1superscriptğµ21B^{2}=1. Assumption â„¬âˆâ€‹(0,1/2)âŠ‚â„¬â€‹(0,d/2)âŠ‚ğ’³subscriptâ„¬012â„¬0ğ‘‘2ğ’³\mathcal{B}_{\infty}(0,1/2)\subset\mathcal{B}(0,\sqrt{d}/2)\subset\mathcal{X} is in TheoremÂ 1 the assumption that â€–x0âˆ’xiâ‹†â€–â©½rnormsuperscriptğ‘¥0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğ‘Ÿ{{\left\|x^{0}-x_{i}^{\star}\right\|}}\leqslant r. In order to obtain a dependency in r>0ğ‘Ÿ0r>0, one simply has to consider the loss (x,Î¾)â†¦â„“â€‹(d2â€‹râ€‹x,Î¾)maps-toğ‘¥ğœ‰â„“ğ‘‘2ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥ğœ‰(x,\xi)\mapsto\ell(\frac{\sqrt{d}}{2r}x,\xi). In order to obtain the dependency in B2superscriptğµ2B^{2}, we need to modify the distribution, and take ğ’Ÿiâ€²=Berâ€‹(1/B2)â€‹B2â€‹ğ’Ÿisuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–â€²Ber1superscriptğµ2superscriptğµ2subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\prime}={\rm Ber}(1/B^{2})B^{2}\mathcal{D}_{i}. In this case, we have a noise amplitude of order B2superscriptğµ2B^{2} instead of order 111, and a factor 1/B21superscriptğµ21/B^{2} appears in the mutual information.

The proof naturally extends to Oracle 1: the mutual information is just Nğ‘N times bigger in that case.

In terms of function distances dâ„‹subscriptğ‘‘â„‹d_{\mathcal{H}} under the assumptions on â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} of TheoremÂ 5, we have, since the distributions are Bernoulli:

dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½|Î´iâˆ’Î´j|â©½biâ€‹j.subscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant|\delta_{i}-\delta_{j}|\leqslant b_{ij}.

We thus proved the first part of TheoremÂ 1.

B.3. Proof of the strongly convex and smooth lower bound: second part of TheoremÂ 1

Let

â„“â€‹(x,Î¾)=12â€‹â€–xâˆ’Î¾â€–2â„“ğ‘¥ğœ‰12superscriptnormğ‘¥ğœ‰2\ell(x,\xi)=\frac{1}{2}{{\left\|x-\xi\right\|}}^{2}\,

for x,Î¾âˆˆâ„dğ‘¥ğœ‰superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x,\xi\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and, for fixed Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0 and any Î±âˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}dğ›¼superscript11ğ‘‘\alpha\in\{-1,1\}^{d}:

gÎ±(x)=12â€‹dâˆ‘k=1d(xk2+1âˆ’2(12+Î±kÎ´)xk),xâˆˆğ’³.g_{\alpha}(x)=\frac{1}{2d}\sum_{k=1}^{d}\Big{(}x_{k}^{2}+1-2\big{(}\frac{1}{2}+\alpha_{k}\delta)x_{k}\Big{)}\quad,x\in\mathcal{X}\,.

We keep the same notations as last subsection (Ïˆâ€‹(Î´),Ïğœ“ğ›¿ğœŒ\psi(\delta),\rho). We have:

Ïâ€‹(gÎ±,gÎ²)=Î´2dâ€‹âˆ‘k=1d|Î±kâˆ’Î²k|.ğœŒsubscriptğ‘”ğ›¼subscriptğ‘”ğ›½superscriptğ›¿2ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ›½ğ‘˜\rho(g_{\alpha},g_{\beta})=\frac{\delta^{2}}{d}\sum_{k=1}^{d}|\alpha_{k}-\beta_{k}|\,.

Similarly to last subsection, this leads to Ïˆâ€‹(Î´)â©¾Î´2/4ğœ“ğ›¿superscriptğ›¿24\psi(\delta)\geqslant\delta^{2}/4 since ğ’±ğ’±\mathcal{V} is a d/4ğ‘‘4d/4-packing of the hypercube.

We keep the same distributions ğ’Ÿ1,â€¦,ğ’ŸNsubscriptğ’Ÿ1â€¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘\mathcal{D}_{1},...,\mathcal{D}_{N} as last subsection, replacing Î´isubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\delta_{i} by Î´i=(Î´âˆ’b1â€‹i)+subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–superscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘1ğ‘–\delta_{i}=(\delta-\sqrt{b_{1i}})^{+}. Agent 1 is still the one that wants to minimize its local generalization error. The mutual information is thus:

Iâ€‹(Ï•T,Î±)â©½C1â€‹Tâ€‹ğ’©1Î´â€‹(b)Nâ€‹Î´2.ğ¼subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘‡ğ›¼subscriptğ¶1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ’©1ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ›¿2I(\phi_{T},\alpha)\leqslant\frac{C_{1}T\mathcal{N}_{1}^{\delta}(\sqrt{b})}{N}\delta^{2}\,.

Setting the target precision as Îµ=Î´2/4ğœ€superscriptğ›¿24\varepsilon=\delta^{2}/4, we obtain:

TÎµâ©¾Câ€²â€‹dâ€‹NÎµâ€‹ğ’©1Îµâ€‹(4â€‹b).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€superscriptğ¶â€²ğ‘‘ğ‘ğœ€superscriptsubscriptğ’©1ğœ€4ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\geqslant C^{\prime}\frac{dN}{\varepsilon\mathcal{N}_{1}^{\varepsilon}(4b)}\,.

The loss function and distributions built verify our regularity assumptions for Î¼=1/dğœ‡1ğ‘‘\mu=1/d, L=1/dğ¿1ğ‘‘L=1/d, noise Ïƒ2â©½1superscriptğœ21\sigma^{2}\leqslant 1.

We verify that for all 1â©½j,kâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘—ğ‘˜ğ‘1\leqslant j,k\leqslant N, we have fjâ€‹(xkâ‹†)âˆ’fjâ€‹(xjâ‹†)â©½bkâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘—f_{j}(x_{k}^{\star})-f_{j}(x_{j}^{\star})\leqslant b_{kj}. We first notice that xjâ‹†=1dâ€‹(12+Î´jâ€‹Î±l)1â©½lâ©½dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†1ğ‘‘subscript12subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘™1ğ‘™ğ‘‘x_{j}^{\star}=\frac{1}{d}\big{(}\frac{1}{2}+\delta_{j}\alpha_{l}\big{)}_{1\leqslant l\leqslant d}, so that:

fjâ€‹(xkâ‹†)âˆ’fjâ€‹(xjâ‹†)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†\displaystyle f_{j}(x_{k}^{\star})-f_{j}(x_{j}^{\star}) =1dâ€‹â€–xjâ‹†âˆ’xkâ‹†â€–2absent1ğ‘‘superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜â‹†2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{d}{{\left\|x_{j}^{\star}-x_{k}^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}
=(Î´iâˆ’Î´k)2absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜2\displaystyle=(\delta_{i}-\delta_{k})^{2}
â©½(b1â€‹jâˆ’b1â€‹k)2absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘—subscriptğ‘1ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\leqslant(\sqrt{b_{1j}}-\sqrt{b_{1k}})^{2}
â©½|b1â€‹jâˆ’b1â€‹k|absentsubscriptğ‘1ğ‘—subscriptğ‘1ğ‘˜\displaystyle\leqslant|b_{1j}-b_{1k}|
â©½bjâ€‹k,absentsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘˜\displaystyle\leqslant b_{jk}\,,

since the weights bğ‘b verify the triangle inequality. Under the assumptions of TheoremÂ 5 on â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}, we have, in terms of distribution-based distances:

dâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿi,ğ’Ÿj)â©½|Î´iâˆ’Î´j|â©½biâ€‹j.subscriptğ‘‘â„‹subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—d_{\mathcal{H}}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}_{j})\leqslant|\delta_{i}-\delta_{j}|\leqslant\sqrt{b_{ij}}\,.

The minimum of each gÎ±subscriptğ‘”ğ›¼g_{\alpha} is attained at xÎ±=12+Î´â€‹Î±superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¼12ğ›¿ğ›¼x^{\alpha}=\frac{1}{2}+\delta\alpha, we thus need to assume as in last subsection that rğ‘Ÿr is of order dğ‘‘\sqrt{d}, and a rescaling leads to the dependency in rğ‘Ÿr. The dependency in Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is obtained as in last subsection.

Appendix C All-for-all lower bound

TheoremÂ 1 immediately yields a Corollary providing lower bounds for the all-to-all problem:

Corollary 1.

Let Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, bğ‘b verifying the triangle inequality, B>0,r>0formulae-sequenceğµ0ğ‘Ÿ0B>0,r>0. Assume that there exists a method â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and some T>0ğ‘‡0T>0 such that, for all ((ğ’Ÿj)j,â„“)âˆˆğ”»â€‹(r,b,B)subscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘—ğ‘—â„“ğ”»ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµ((\mathcal{D}_{j})_{j},\ell)\in\mathbb{D}(r,b,B), â„³â„³\mathcal{M} returns (x1,â€¦,xN)subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘(x_{1},\ldots,x_{N}) verifying:

1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(xi)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½Îµ.1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ€\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant\varepsilon\,.

where Tğ‘‡T is the number of stochastic gradients sampled from all agents. Then we have:

Tâ©¾Câ€‹r2â€‹B2N2â€‹Îµ2â€‹âˆ‘i=1N1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b4â€‹N).ğ‘‡ğ¶superscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptğµ2superscriptğ‘2superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘4ğ‘T\geqslant\frac{Cr^{2}B^{2}}{N^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(\frac{b}{4N})}\,.

Replacing ğ”»â€‹(r,b,B)ğ”»ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğµ\mathbb{D}(r,b,B) by ğ”»Î¼=1/r2L=1/r2â€‹(r,b,Ïƒ)superscriptsubscriptğ”»ğœ‡1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ¿1superscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğœ\mathbb{D}_{\mu=1/r^{2}}^{L=1/r^{2}}(r,b,\sigma), we have:

Tâ©¾Câ€²â€‹r2â€‹Ïƒ2Nâ€‹Îµâ€‹âˆ‘i=1N1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(b4â€‹N).ğ‘‡superscriptğ¶â€²superscriptğ‘Ÿ2superscriptğœ2ğ‘ğœ€superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€ğ‘4ğ‘T\geqslant\frac{C^{\prime}r^{2}\sigma^{2}}{N\varepsilon}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(\frac{b}{4N})}\,.

Appendix D All-for-one upper-bounds

We provide the following relaxation of bias assumptionÂ B.2, a generalization of classical function dissimilarities assumptions Karimireddy etÂ al. [2020], Chayti etÂ al. [2021] to our setting.

  1. B.3

    For all 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N, for any stochastic vector Î»âˆˆâ„Nğœ†superscriptâ„ğ‘\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N} (non-negative entries that sum to 1), and for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where gÎ»â€‹(x)=âˆ‘j=1NÎ»jâ€‹âˆ‡fjâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥g_{\lambda}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}\nabla f_{j}(x):

    â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’gÎ»â€‹(x)â€–2â©½mâ€‹â€–gÎ»â€‹(x)â€–2+âˆ‘j=1NÎ»jâ€‹b~iâ€‹j.superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘¥2ğ‘šsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘¥2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-g_{\lambda}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\leqslant m{{\left\|g_{\lambda}(x)\right\|}}^{2}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}\tilde{b}_{ij}\,. (13)

In a similar setting (Nğ‘N agents with heterogeneous functions), Karimireddy etÂ al. [2020], Deng etÂ al. [2020], Chayti etÂ al. [2021] assume that for a fixed agent (or for any agent) iğ‘–i, â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fÂ¯â€‹(x)â€–2â©½mâ€‹â€–âˆ‡fÂ¯â€‹(x)â€–2+Î¶2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡Â¯ğ‘“ğ‘¥2ğ‘šsuperscriptnormâˆ‡Â¯ğ‘“ğ‘¥2superscriptğœ2{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla\bar{f}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\leqslant m{{\left\|\nabla\bar{f}(x)\right\|}}^{2}+\zeta^{2} (or similar assumptions) where fÂ¯Â¯ğ‘“\bar{f} is the mean of all functions. (B.2) is the simplest relaxation of this to the more general setting where all agents want to minimize their local function, whileÂ (B.3) is a relaxation that keeps the less-restrictive first term for some mâ©¾0ğ‘š0m\geqslant 0.

We prove the following intermediate result.

Theorem 6 (WGA).

Let (xk)kâ©¾0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘˜0(x^{k})_{k\geqslant 0} be generated with (6), for some fixed stochastic vector Î»âˆˆâ„Nğœ†superscriptâ„ğ‘\lambda\in\mathbb{R}^{N}, stepsize Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0. Let 1â©½iâ©½N1ğ‘–ğ‘1\leqslant i\leqslant N fixed. Let bâˆˆâ„+NÃ—Nğ‘superscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘b\in{\mathbb{R}^{+}}^{N\times N}. Denote Fik=fiâ€‹(xk)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†F_{i}^{k}=f_{i}(x^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star}).

  1. 6.a

    Use the asynchronous oracle. Assume that for all kâ©¾0ğ‘˜0k\geqslant 0 and iğ‘–i, â€–xkâˆ’xiâ‹†â€–â©½Dnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğ·{{\left\|x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\right\|}}\leqslant D for some D>0ğ·0D>0. If fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is convex, noise assumptionÂ (N.1) holds for some B>0ğµ0B>0 and bias assumptionÂ (B.2) holds for b~=(b/D)2~ğ‘superscriptğ‘ğ·2\tilde{b}=(b/D)^{2}, for any K>0ğ¾0K>0 and for Î·=D22â€‹Kâ€‹Nâ€‹B2â€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»j2ğœ‚superscriptğ·22ğ¾ğ‘superscriptğµ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2\eta=\sqrt{\frac{D^{2}}{2KNB^{2}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}^{2}}}:

    ğ”¼â€‹[1Kâ€‹âˆ‘0â©½k<KFik]ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ¾subscript0ğ‘˜ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘˜\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{0\leqslant k<K}F_{i}^{k}\right] â©½2â€‹D2â€‹B2KNâ€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»j2+âˆ‘1â©½jâ©½NÎ»jâ€‹biâ€‹j.absent2superscriptğ·2superscriptğµ2ğ¾ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2subscript1ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2D^{2}B^{2}}{\frac{K}{N}}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}^{2}}+\sum_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}\lambda_{j}b_{ij}\,.
  2. 6.b

    Use the synchronous oracle. Assume that all fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} are Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex and Lğ¿L-smooth (denote Îº=L/Î¼ğœ…ğ¿ğœ‡\kappa=L/\mu), satisfy noise assumptionÂ N.2 for some Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0, that one of bias assumptionsÂ (B.2) orÂ (B.3) holds for b~=Î¼â€‹b~ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘\tilde{b}=\mu b (and any mâ©¾0ğ‘š0m\geqslant 0). For any K>0ğ¾0K>0 and Î·=minâ¡(1/(2â€‹L),1Î¼â€‹Kâ€‹lnâ¡(FÎ»0â€‹Î¼2â€‹KLâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆ‘jÎ»j2))ğœ‚12ğ¿1ğœ‡ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğœ†0superscriptğœ‡2ğ¾ğ¿superscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2\eta=\min(1/(2L),\frac{1}{\mu K}\ln(\frac{F_{\lambda}^{0}\mu^{2}K}{L\sigma^{2}}\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}^{2})) where FÎ»0=âˆ‘jÎ»jâ€‹(fjâ€‹(x0)âˆ’fjâ€‹(xjâ‹†))superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğœ†0subscriptğ‘—subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†F_{\lambda}^{0}=\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}(f_{j}(x^{0})-f_{j}(x_{j}^{\star})), we have:

    ğ”¼â€‹[FiK]â©½ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ¾absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F_{i}^{K}\right]\leqslant 2â€‹(m+1)â€‹Îºâ€‹(FÎ»0â€‹eâˆ’K2â€‹Îº+ğ’ª~â€‹(Lâ€‹Ïƒ2Î¼2â€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½jâ©½NÎ»j2))+âˆ‘1â©½jâ©½NÎ»jâ€‹biâ€‹j.2ğ‘š1ğœ…superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğœ†0superscriptğ‘’ğ¾2ğœ…~ğ’ªğ¿superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ‡2ğ¾subscript1ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2subscript1ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle 2(m+1)\kappa\left(F_{\lambda}^{0}e^{-\frac{K}{2\kappa}}+\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{L\sigma^{2}}{\mu^{2}K}\sum_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}\lambda_{j}^{2}\right)\right)+\sum_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}\lambda_{j}b_{ij}\,.

This leads to a more general sample complexity in SettingÂ 2, where we can use (B.3).

Theorem 7.

Let Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, and set Î»j=ğŸ™{biâ€‹j<Îµ/2}ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\lambda_{j}=\frac{\mathds{1}_{{{\left\{b_{ij}<\varepsilon/2\right\}}}}}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}, ğ’©iÎµsuperscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon} being defined in TheoremÂ 1. Generate (xk)ksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘˜(x^{k})_{k} usingÂ (6).

  1. 7.1

    Under SettingÂ 1. Assume that for all kâ©¾0ğ‘˜0k\geqslant 0 and iğ‘–i, â€–xkâˆ’xiâ‹†â€–â©½Dnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğ·{{\left\|x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\right\|}}\leqslant D for some D>0ğ·0D>0 and bias assumptionÂ (B.2) holds for b~=(b/D)2~ğ‘superscriptğ‘ğ·2\tilde{b}=(b/D)^{2}. For K=TÎµğ¾subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€K=T_{\varepsilon} and for Î·=D22â€‹Kâ€‹Nâ€‹B2â€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»j2ğœ‚superscriptğ·22ğ¾ğ‘superscriptğµ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2\eta=\sqrt{\frac{D^{2}}{2KNB^{2}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}^{2}}}, we have ğ”¼â€‹[1Kâ€‹âˆ‘0â©½k<Kfiâ€‹(xk)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)]â©½Îµğ”¼delimited-[]1ğ¾subscript0ğ‘˜ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ€\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{K}\sum_{0\leqslant k<K}f_{i}(x^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]\leqslant\varepsilon using a total number TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} of stochastic gradients from all agents of:

    TÎµâ©½4â€‹D2â€‹B2Îµ2â€‹Nğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€4superscriptğ·2superscriptğµ2superscriptğœ€2ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\frac{4D^{2}B^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\,.
  2. 7.2

    Under SettingÂ 2. Denote Îº=L/Î¼ğœ…ğ¿ğœ‡\kappa=L/\mu, assume that one of bias assumptionsÂ (B.2) orÂ (B.3) holds for b~=Î¼â€‹b~ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘\tilde{b}=\mu b (and any mâ©¾0ğ‘š0m\geqslant 0). For K=TÎµ/Nğ¾subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€ğ‘K=T_{\varepsilon}/N and Î·=minâ¡(1/(2â€‹L),1Î¼â€‹Kâ€‹lnâ¡(FÎ»0â€‹Î¼2â€‹KLâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹âˆ‘jÎ»j2))ğœ‚12ğ¿1ğœ‡ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğœ†0superscriptğœ‡2ğ¾ğ¿superscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2\eta=\min(1/(2L),\frac{1}{\mu K}\ln(\frac{F_{\lambda}^{0}\mu^{2}K}{L\sigma^{2}}\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}^{2})) where FÎ»0=âˆ‘jÎ»jâ€‹(fjâ€‹(x0)âˆ’fjâ€‹(xjâ‹†))superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğœ†0subscriptğ‘—subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†F_{\lambda}^{0}=\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}(f_{j}(x^{0})-f_{j}(x_{j}^{\star})), we have ğ”¼â€‹[fiâ€‹(xK)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)]â©½Îµğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†ğœ€\mathbb{E}\left[f_{i}(x^{K})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\right]\leqslant\varepsilon using a total number TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} of stochastic gradients from all agents of:

    TÎµâ©½ğ’ª~â€‹((m+1)â€‹Îº2â€‹Ïƒ2Î¼â€‹Îµâ€‹Nğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)),subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€~ğ’ªğ‘š1superscriptğœ…2superscriptğœ2ğœ‡ğœ€ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{(m+1)\kappa^{2}\sigma^{2}}{\mu\varepsilon}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\right)\,,

    and of

    TÎµâ©½ğ’ª~â€‹(Îºâ€‹Ïƒ2Î¼â€‹Îµâ€‹Nğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)),subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€~ğ’ªğœ…superscriptğœ2ğœ‡ğœ€ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{\kappa\sigma^{2}}{\mu\varepsilon}\frac{N}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\right)\,,

    if mâ©½1/2ğ‘š12m\leqslant 1/2.

In TheoremÂ 6.b upper-bound, the first term is the optimization term, and vanishes exponentially quickly in front of the second and third ones (if they are non null), and is not reminiscent of our personalized problem. The second is the noise term (referred to as the statistical term), while the third is a bias term, making appear as advertised in the introduction a bias-variance trade-off. In TheoremÂ 6.a, only the statistical and the bias terms are present. In both cases, a right choice of Î»iâ€‹jsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—\lambda_{ij} matches the lower bound of TheoremÂ 1 in terms of sample complexity, for Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 small enough such that the optimization term vanishes in front of the statistical one. In TheoremÂ 6.a, Dğ·D plays the role of rğ‘Ÿr in the lower bound (and can be more restrictive). Parameters Î¼,Lğœ‡ğ¿\mu,L in TheoremÂ 6.b can take any value, while they are fixed in our lower bounds (with Îº=1ğœ…1\kappa=1).

For the two proofs below, we write

gÎ»kâ€‹(x)=âˆ‘j=1NÎ»jâ€‹Gkâ€‹(x)j.superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘˜ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—superscriptğºğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—g_{\lambda}^{k}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}G^{k}(x)_{j}\,.

D.1. Proof of TheoremÂ 6.a

Assume first that the fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} are differentiable. Observe first that under noise assumptionÂ (N.1) and with the asynchronous oracle:

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gÎ»kâ€‹(x)â€–2]â©½âˆ‘j=1NNâ€‹Î»j2â€‹B2,xâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequenceğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘˜ğ‘¥2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2superscriptğµ2ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{\lambda}^{k}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant\sum_{j=1}^{N}N\lambda_{j}^{2}B^{2}\,,\quad x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\,.

We now proceed following classical SGD analysis, but with biased gradients here. Denote eik=ğ”¼â€‹[â€–xkâˆ’xiâ‹†â€–2]superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†2e_{i}^{k}=\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}\right]. We have:

eik+1superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘˜1\displaystyle e_{i}^{k+1} =eikâˆ’2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âŸ¨âˆ‘j=1NÎ»jâ€‹âˆ‡fjâ€‹(xk),xkâˆ’xiâ‹†âŸ©]+Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gÎ»kâ€–â€‹(xk)]absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘˜2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼delimited-[]normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\displaystyle=e_{i}^{k}-2\mathbb{E}\left[\langle\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}\nabla f_{j}(x^{k}),x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\rangle\right]+\eta^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{\lambda}^{k}\right\|}}(x^{k})\right]
â©½eikâˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âŸ¨âˆ‡fâ€‹(xk),xkâˆ’xiâ‹†âŸ©]+ğŸâ€‹ğœ¼â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âŸ¨âˆ‡ğ’‡â€‹(ğ’™ğ’Œ)âˆ’âˆ‘ğ’‹=ğŸğ‘µğ€ğ’‹â€‹âˆ‡ğ’‡ğ’‹â€‹(ğ’™ğ’Œ),ğ’™ğ’Œâˆ’ğ’™ğ’Šâ‹†âŸ©]+Î·2â€‹âˆ‘j=1NNâ€‹Î»j2â€‹B2,absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘˜2ğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†2ğœ¼ğ”¼delimited-[]bold-âˆ‡ğ’‡superscriptğ’™ğ’Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ’‹1ğ‘µsubscriptğ€ğ’‹bold-âˆ‡subscriptğ’‡ğ’‹superscriptğ’™ğ’Œsuperscriptğ’™ğ’Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ’Šbold-â‹†superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2superscriptğµ2\displaystyle\leqslant e_{i}^{k}-2\eta\mathbb{E}\left[\langle\nabla f(x^{k}),x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\rangle\right]+\boldsymbol{2\eta\mathbb{E}\left[\langle\nabla f(x^{k})-\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}\nabla f_{j}(x^{k}),x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\rangle\right]}+\eta^{2}\sum_{j=1}^{N}N\lambda_{j}^{2}B^{2}\,,

where the bold term is the bias term, that we bound by Dâ€‹âˆ‘jÎ»jâ€‹b~iâ€‹j=âˆ‘jÎ»jâ€‹biâ€‹jğ·subscriptğ‘—subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘—subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—D\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}\sqrt{\tilde{b}_{ij}}=\sum_{j}\lambda_{j}b_{ij} using bias assumptionÂ (2) and b~iâ€‹j=(biâ€‹j/D)2subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ·2\tilde{b}_{ij}=(b_{ij}/D)^{2}. Then, since âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âŸ¨âˆ‡fâ€‹(xk),xkâˆ’xiâ‹†âŸ©]â©½âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹Fik2ğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†2ğœ‚ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘˜-2\eta\mathbb{E}\left[\langle\nabla f(x^{k}),x^{k}-x_{i}^{\star}\rangle\right]\leqslant-2\eta\mathbb{E}F_{i}^{k}, we have, summing the above inequality for 1â©½kâ©½K1ğ‘˜ğ¾1\leqslant k\leqslant K:

âˆ‘k=0Kâˆ’1Fikâ©½ei02â€‹Î·+Kâ€‹Î·2â€‹Nâ€‹B2â€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»j2+Kâ€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»jâ€‹biâ€‹j.superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¾1superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–02ğœ‚ğ¾ğœ‚2ğ‘superscriptğµ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}F_{i}^{k}\leqslant\frac{e_{i}^{0}}{2\eta}+K\frac{\eta}{2}NB^{2}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}^{2}+K\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}b_{ij}\,.

We obtain the desired result by dividing by Kğ¾K and for the choice of Î·ğœ‚\eta as in TheoremÂ 3.a. In the case where we have access to subdifferentials only, the proof stays identical (as in LemmaÂ 6).

D.2. Proof of TheoremÂ 6.b

Denoting fÎ»â€‹(x)=âˆ‘j=1NÎ»jâ€‹fjâ€‹(x)superscriptğ‘“ğœ†ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘¥f^{\lambda}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}f_{j}(x), observe that fÎ»superscriptğ‘“ğœ†f^{\lambda} is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex and Lğ¿L-smooth, and for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, under the synchronous oracle and noise assumptionÂ (N.2):

ğ”¼â€‹[gÎ»kâ€‹(x)]=âˆ‡fÎ»â€‹(x),ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘˜ğ‘¥âˆ‡superscriptğ‘“ğœ†ğ‘¥\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[g_{\lambda}^{k}(x)\right]=\nabla f^{\lambda}(x)\,, (14)
ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gÎ»kâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fÎ»â€‹(x)â€–2]â©½Ïƒ2â€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»j2.ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğœ†ğ‘˜ğ‘¥âˆ‡superscriptğ‘“ğœ†ğ‘¥2superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{\lambda}^{k}(x)-\nabla f^{\lambda}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant\sigma^{2}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{j}^{2}\,.

Applying LemmaÂ 4 (SGD under strong convexity and smoothness assumptions), we have, where xÎ»superscriptğ‘¥ğœ†x^{\lambda} minimizes fÎ»superscriptğ‘“ğœ†f^{\lambda}:

fÎ»â€‹(xk)âˆ’fÎ»â€‹(xÎ»)â©½FÎ»0â€‹eâˆ’k2â€‹Îº+ğ’ª~â€‹(Lâ€‹Ïƒ2Î¼2â€‹kâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½jâ©½NÎ»j2).superscriptğ‘“ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘“ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ¹ğœ†0superscriptğ‘’ğ‘˜2ğœ…~ğ’ªğ¿superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘˜subscript1ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—2f^{\lambda}(x^{k})-f^{\lambda}(x^{\lambda})\leqslant F_{\lambda}^{0}e^{-\frac{k}{2\kappa}}+\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\frac{L\sigma^{2}}{\mu^{2}k}\sum_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}\lambda_{j}^{2}\right)\,.

Then, under either bias assumptionÂ (B.2) orÂ (B.3), we have:

â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xk)â€–2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2\displaystyle{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2} â©½2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xk)âˆ’âˆ‡fÎ»â€‹(xk)â€–2+2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fÎ»â€‹(xk)â€–2absent2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜âˆ‡superscriptğ‘“ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜22superscriptnormâˆ‡superscriptğ‘“ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\leqslant 2{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x^{k})-\nabla f^{\lambda}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2}+2{{\left\|\nabla f^{\lambda}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2}
â©½2â€‹(mâ€‹â€–âˆ‡fÎ»â€‹(xk)â€–2+âˆ‘j=1NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹b~iâ€‹j)+2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fÎ»â€‹(xk)â€–2absent2ğ‘šsuperscriptnormâˆ‡superscriptğ‘“ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—2superscriptnormâˆ‡superscriptğ‘“ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\leqslant 2(m{{\left\|\nabla f^{\lambda}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{ij}\tilde{b}_{ij})+2{{\left\|\nabla f^{\lambda}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2}
â©½2â€‹âˆ‘j=1NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹b~iâ€‹j+4â€‹Lâ€‹(m+1)â€‹(fÎ»â€‹(xk)âˆ’fÎ»â€‹(xÎ»)).absent2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—4ğ¿ğ‘š1superscriptğ‘“ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘“ğœ†superscriptğ‘¥ğœ†\displaystyle\leqslant 2\sum_{j=1}^{N}\lambda_{ij}\tilde{b}_{ij}+4L(m+1)(f^{\lambda}(x^{k})-f^{\lambda}(x^{\lambda}))\,.

We conclude using fiâ€‹(xk)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½12â€‹Î¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xk)â€–2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†12ğœ‡superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2f_{i}(x^{k})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant\frac{1}{2\mu}{{\left\|\nabla f_{i}(x^{k})\right\|}}^{2} and b~iâ€‹j=Î¼â€‹biâ€‹jsubscript~ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ‡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\tilde{b}_{ij}=\mu b_{ij}.

This result is valid under any mâ©¾0ğ‘š0m\geqslant 0, and gives the first part of TheoremÂ 7.2. If mâ©½1/2ğ‘š12m\leqslant 1/2, one can use Theorem 1 inÂ Chayti etÂ al. [2021] with the set of agents jğ‘—j such that biâ€‹jâ©½Îµsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€b_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon, agent 00 is agent iğ‘–i, with Î±=1/ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)ğ›¼1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\alpha=1/\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b), to obtain the sample complexity without the Îºğœ…\kappa factor.

Appendix E All-for-all upper-bounds

We first begin with the following simple lemma.

Lemma 3.

If Î›Î›\Lambda is a stochastic matrix and if bias assumptionÂ (B.1) holds (fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)â©½biâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star})\leqslant b_{ij} for all 1â©½i,jâ©½Nformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N):

fÎ›â€‹(xÎ›)âˆ’fÂ¯â€‹(xâ‹†)â©½1Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹biâ€‹j.superscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¥Î›Â¯ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†1ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—f^{\Lambda}(x^{\Lambda})-\bar{f}(x^{\star})\leqslant\frac{1}{N}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}b_{ij}\,.
Proof.

Writing the optimality of xÎ›superscriptğ‘¥Î›x^{\Lambda} gives:

fÎ›â€‹(xÎ›)superscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¥Î›\displaystyle f^{\Lambda}(x^{\Lambda}) â©½fÎ›â€‹(xâ‹†)absentsuperscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¥â‹†\displaystyle\leqslant f^{\Lambda}(x^{\star})
=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘ifiâ€‹(âˆ‘jÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹xjâ‹†)absent1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†\displaystyle=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i}f_{i}(\sum_{j}\lambda_{ij}x_{j}^{\star})
â©½1Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†),absent1ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†\displaystyle\leqslant\frac{1}{N}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})\,,

where we used convexity of each fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}. Then, subtracting fÂ¯â€‹(xâ‹†)Â¯ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†\bar{f}(x^{\star}) and using stochasticity of Î›Î›\Lambda:

fÎ›â€‹(xÎ›)âˆ’fÂ¯â€‹(xâ‹†)â©½1Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹(fiâ€‹(xjâ‹†)âˆ’fiâ€‹(xiâ‹†)).superscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¥Î›Â¯ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†1ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—â‹†subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â‹†\displaystyle f^{\Lambda}(x^{\Lambda})-\bar{f}(x^{\star})\leqslant\frac{1}{N}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}(f_{i}(x_{j}^{\star})-f_{i}(x_{i}^{\star}))\,.

âˆ

E.1. Proof of TheoremÂ 3.a

Using LemmaÂ 3 and the proof sketch (fÎ›â€‹(yk)=fÂ¯â€‹(xk)superscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜f^{\Lambda}(y^{k})=\bar{f}(x^{k}) and the bias variance decomposition):

fÂ¯â€‹(xk)âˆ’fÂ¯â€‹(xâ‹†)â©½fÎ›â€‹(yk)âˆ’fÎ›â€‹(xÎ›)+1Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹biâ€‹j,Â¯ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘“Î›superscriptğ‘¥Î›1ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\bar{f}(x^{k})-\bar{f}(x^{\star})\leqslant f^{\Lambda}(y^{k})-f^{\Lambda}(x^{\Lambda})+\frac{1}{N}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}b_{ij}\,,

where (yk)superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜(y^{k}) is generated using simple SGD on fÎ›superscriptğ‘“Î›f^{\Lambda}:

yk+1=ykâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡GÎ›kâ€‹(yk),superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğœ‚âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘˜Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y^{k+1}=y^{k}-\eta\nabla G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y^{k})\,,

where

GÎ›k(y)=(Î»ikâ€‹jgikk((Î›yk)ik)))1â©½jâ©½N.G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y)=\big{(}\lambda_{i_{k}j}g_{i_{k}}^{k}((\Lambda y^{k})_{i_{k}}))\big{)}_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}\,.

fÎ›superscriptğ‘“Î›f^{\Lambda} is convex, and we have under noise assumptionÂ (N.1) for the asynchronous oracle, under differentiable assumptions:

ğ”¼â€‹[GÎ›kâ€‹(y)]=âˆ‡fÎ›â€‹(y),ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘˜Î›ğ‘¦âˆ‡superscriptğ‘“Î›ğ‘¦\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y)\right]=\nabla f^{\Lambda}(y)\,,
ğ”¼â€‹[â€–GÎ›kâ€‹(y)â€–2]â©½B2Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹j2.ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘˜Î›ğ‘¦2superscriptğµ2ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant\frac{B^{2}}{N}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}^{2}\,.

If we only have subdifferentials, we still have ğ”¼â€‹[GÎ›kâ€‹(y)]âˆˆâˆ‚fÎ›â€‹(y)ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘˜Î›ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘“Î›ğ‘¦\mathbb{E}\left[G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y)\right]\in\partial f^{\Lambda}(y). Using LemmaÂ 6 (SGD under these assumptions), we obtain the desired result.

E.2. Proof of TheoremÂ 3.b

Under noise assumptionÂ (N.2) and for the synchronous oracle, we stil have:

yk+1=ykâˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡GÎ›kâ€‹(yk),superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜1superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜ğœ‚âˆ‡subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘˜Î›superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘˜y^{k+1}=y^{k}-\eta\nabla G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y^{k})\,,

for

GÎ›k(y)=1N(âˆ‘i=1NÎ»iâ€‹jgik((Î›yk)i)))1â©½jâ©½N,G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y)=\frac{1}{N}\big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\lambda_{ij}g_{i}^{k}((\Lambda y^{k})_{i}))\big{)}_{1\leqslant j\leqslant N}\,,

that verifies:

ğ”¼â€‹[GÎ›kâ€‹(y)]=âˆ‡fÎ›â€‹(y),ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘˜Î›ğ‘¦âˆ‡superscriptğ‘“Î›ğ‘¦\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y)\right]=\nabla f^{\Lambda}(y)\,,
ğ”¼â€‹[â€–GÎ›kâ€‹(y)âˆ’âˆ‡fÎ»â€‹(y)â€–2]â©½Ïƒ2N2â€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹j2.ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘˜Î›ğ‘¦âˆ‡superscriptğ‘“ğœ†ğ‘¦2superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘2subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|G^{k}_{\Lambda}(y)-\nabla f^{\lambda}(y)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N^{2}}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}^{2}\,.

The function fÎ›superscriptğ‘“Î›f^{\Lambda} is however not necessarily strongly convex. However, since âˆ‡2fÎ›â€‹(y)=Î›âŠ¤â€‹âˆ‡2fÂ¯â€‹(Î›â€‹y)â€‹Î›superscriptâˆ‡2superscriptğ‘“Î›ğ‘¦superscriptÎ›topsuperscriptâˆ‡2Â¯ğ‘“Î›ğ‘¦Î›\nabla^{2}f^{\Lambda}(y)=\Lambda^{\top}\nabla^{2}\bar{f}(\Lambda y)\Lambda and fÂ¯Â¯ğ‘“\bar{f} is L/Nğ¿ğ‘L/N-smooth and Î¼/Nğœ‡ğ‘\mu/N-strongly convex, fÎ›superscriptğ‘“Î›f^{\Lambda} is L/Nğ¿ğ‘L/N-relatively smooth and Î¼/Nğœ‡ğ‘\mu/N-relatively strongly convex [Bauschke etÂ al., 2017] with respect to 12â€‹â€–yâ€–W2=12â€‹yâŠ¤â€‹Wâ€‹y12superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¦ğ‘Š212superscriptğ‘¦topğ‘Šğ‘¦\frac{1}{2}{{\left\|y\right\|}}_{W}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}y^{\top}Wy. Note also that the spectral radius of Wğ‘ŠW is 111, since Î›Î›\Lambda is stochastic. Instead of using stochastic Bregman gradient descent (e.g.Â Dragomir etÂ al. [2021]), we use LemmaÂ 4: classical SGD that naturally generalizes to relative smoothness and strong convexity assumptions, when the mirror map is quadratic.

E.3. Time-adaptive variant

Proposition 3 (Time-adaptive all-for-all).

Assume that the same assumptions as in TheoremÂ 3.a hold. For any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, denote Î›Îµ=(ğŸ™2â€‹biâ€‹jâ©½Îµğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)\Lambda_{\varepsilon}=(\frac{\mathds{1}_{2b_{ij}\leqslant\varepsilon}}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}, KÎµ=4â€‹D2â€‹B2Îµ2â€‹âˆ‘i=1N1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)subscriptğ¾ğœ€4superscriptğ·2superscriptğµ2superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘K_{\varepsilon}=\frac{4D^{2}B^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)} and Î·â€‹(Îµ)=2â€‹Nâ€‹D2KÎµâ€‹B2â€‹âˆ‘i1/ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)ğœ‚ğœ€2ğ‘superscriptğ·2subscriptğ¾ğœ€superscriptğµ2subscriptğ‘–1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\eta(\varepsilon)=\frac{2ND^{2}}{K_{\varepsilon}B^{2}\sum_{i}1/\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}. For any kâ©¾0ğ‘˜0k\geqslant 0, there exists pkâ©¾0subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜0p_{k}\geqslant 0 such that âˆ‘q=0pkâˆ’1T2âˆ’qâ©½k<âˆ‘q=0pkT2âˆ’qsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘‡superscript2ğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‡superscript2ğ‘\sum_{q=0}^{p_{k}-1}T_{2^{-q}}\leqslant k<\sum_{q=0}^{p_{k}}T_{2^{-q}}, and choose:

Î·k=Î·â€‹(2âˆ’pk),W(k)=Î›2âˆ’pkâ€‹Î›2âˆ’pkâŠ¤.formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜ğœ‚superscript2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘Šğ‘˜subscriptÎ›superscript2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptÎ›superscript2subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜top\displaystyle\eta_{k}=\eta(2^{-p_{k}})\,,\quad W^{(k)}=\Lambda_{2^{-p_{k}}}\Lambda_{2^{-p_{k}}}^{\top}\,.

Then, for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, the iterates generated by AlgorithmÂ 2 reach averaged precision Îµğœ€\varepsilon for a number of data item sampled from personal distribution of:

TÎµâ©½16â€‹D2â€‹B2Îµ2â€‹âˆ‘i=1N1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b),subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€16superscriptğ·2superscriptğµ2superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\frac{16D^{2}B^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)}\,,

Similarly, under strong-convexity and smoothness assumptions as in TheoremÂ 3.b, one would obtain the corresponding sample complexity, up to a factor 2.

E.4. SettingÂ 2 under Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0

Theorem 8 (All-for-all, convex case).

Let K>0ğ¾0K>0, Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0, and Wğ‘ŠW a symmetric non-negative random matrix of the form W=Î›â€‹Î›âŠ¤ğ‘ŠÎ›superscriptÎ›topW=\Lambda\Lambda^{\top} for some stochastic matrix Î›=(Î»iâ€‹j)1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ›subscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—formulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘\Lambda=(\lambda_{ij})_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}. Let (xik)kâ©¾0,1â©½iâ©½Nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘˜formulae-sequenceğ‘˜01ğ‘–ğ‘(x_{i}^{k})_{k\geqslant 0,1\leqslant i\leqslant N} be generated with AlgorithmÂ 1. Assume that bias assumptionÂ (B.1) holds for some (biâ€‹j)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—(b_{ij}). Under Setting 2, for Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0 (convex case), if Î·=N3/2â€‹DÏƒâ€‹âˆ‘i,jÎ»iâ€‹j2âˆ§N2â€‹Lğœ‚superscriptğ‘32ğ·ğœsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—2ğ‘2ğ¿\eta=\frac{N^{3/2}D}{\sigma\sqrt{\sum_{i,j}\lambda_{ij}^{2}}}\wedge\frac{N}{2L}, where â€–xi0âˆ’xiÎ›â€–â©½Dnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Î›ğ·{{\left\|x_{i}^{0}-x_{i}^{\Lambda}\right\|}}\leqslant D for all iğ‘–i, we have:

ğ”¼â€‹[FK]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ¹ğ¾\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F^{K}\right] â©½2â€‹Lâ€‹D2K+2â€‹D2â€‹Ïƒ2Kâ€‹Nâ€‹âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹j2+âˆ‘1â©½i,jâ©½NÎ»iâ€‹jâ€‹biâ€‹j.absent2ğ¿superscriptğ·2ğ¾2superscriptğ·2superscriptğœ2ğ¾ğ‘subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—2subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\leqslant\frac{2LD^{2}}{K}+\sqrt{\frac{2D^{2}\sigma^{2}}{KN}\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}^{2}}+\sum_{1\leqslant i,j\leqslant N}\lambda_{ij}b_{ij}\,.\vspace{-5pt}

Consequently, for Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, and a choice of W=Î›â€‹Î›âŠ¤ğ‘ŠÎ›superscriptÎ›topW=\Lambda\Lambda^{\top} for Î»iâ€‹j=ğŸ™{biâ€‹j<Îµ/2}ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b)subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—subscript1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘\lambda_{ij}=\frac{\mathds{1}_{{\left\{b_{ij}<\varepsilon/2\right\}}}}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)} and under the same assumptions, the all-for-all algorithm reaches ğ”¼â€‹[FK]â©½Îµğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ¹ğ¾ğœ€\mathbb{E}\left[F^{K}\right]\leqslant\varepsilon for a total number TÎµsubscriptğ‘‡ğœ€T_{\varepsilon} of data item sampled from personal distributions of:

TÎµâ©½maxâ¡(8â€‹D2â€‹Ïƒ2Îµ2â€‹âˆ‘i=1N1ğ’©iÎµâ€‹(2â€‹b),4â€‹Nâ€‹Lâ€‹D2Îµ)subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€8superscriptğ·2superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ’©ğ‘–ğœ€2ğ‘4ğ‘ğ¿superscriptğ·2ğœ€T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\max\left(\frac{8D^{2}\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{\mathcal{N}_{i}^{\varepsilon}(2b)},\,\frac{4NLD^{2}}{\varepsilon}\right)
Proof.

Combining LemmaÂ 5 with the noise variance and regularity parameters of FÎ›superscriptğ¹Î›F^{\Lambda}. âˆ

Appendix F Stochastic Optimization Toolbox

F.1. SGD under strongly convex and smooth assumptions

Lemma 4 (SGD, s.c. and smooth).

Define â€–xâ€–A2=xâŠ¤â€‹Aâ€‹xsuperscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¥ğ´2superscriptğ‘¥topğ´ğ‘¥{{\left\|x\right\|}}_{A}^{2}=x^{\top}Ax for some non-negative and symmetric matrix Ağ´A. Let f:ğ’³â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’ğ’³â„f:\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R} Î¼ğœ‡\mu-relatively strongly convex and Lğ¿L-relatively smooth with respect to 12â€‹â€–xâ€–A212superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¥ğ´2\frac{1}{2}{{\left\|x\right\|}}_{A}^{2}. Let (ft,gt)tâ©¾0subscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(f_{t},g_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be first order oracle calls such that for all tâ©¾0ğ‘¡0t\geqslant 0:

âˆ€xâˆˆğ’³,{ğ”¼â€‹[ftâ€‹(x)]=fâ€‹(x),ğ”¼â€‹[gtâ€‹(x)]=âˆ‡fâ€‹(x),ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gtâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(x)â€–2]â©½Ïƒ2,\forall x\in\mathcal{X}\,,\quad\left\{\begin{aligned} &\mathbb{E}\left[f_{t}(x)\right]=f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[g_{t}(x)\right]=\nabla f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}(x)-\nabla f(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant\sigma^{2}\,,\end{aligned}\right.

for some Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0. Let LAsubscriptğ¿ğ´L_{A} be the largest eigenvalue of Ağ´A, and assume that LAâ©½1subscriptğ¿ğ´1L_{A}\leqslant 1 (our result generalizes to any LAsubscriptğ¿ğ´L_{A}). Let (xt)tâ©¾0subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(x_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be generated with:

âˆ€tâ©¾0,xt+1=xtâˆ’Î·â€‹gtâ€‹(xt),formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¡0superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\forall t\geqslant 0\,,\quad x^{t+1}=x^{t}-\eta g_{t}(x^{t})\,,

for a fixed stepsize 12â€‹Lâ©¾Î·>012ğ¿ğœ‚0\frac{1}{2L}\geqslant\eta>0, and assume that all the iterates lie in ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}. Assume that fğ‘“f is minimized over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} at some interior point xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star}. We have for any T>0ğ‘‡0T>0:

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(xT)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)]â©½eâˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼â€‹Tâ€‹(fâ€‹(x0)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†))+Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Ïƒ2Î¼.ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğ‘’ğœ‚ğœ‡ğ‘‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğœ2ğœ‡\mathbb{E}\left[f(x^{T})-f(x^{\star})\right]\leqslant e^{-\eta\mu T}\big{(}f(x^{0})-f(x^{\star})\big{)}+\frac{\eta L\sigma^{2}}{\mu}\,.

For fixed T>0ğ‘‡0T>0, setting Î·=minâ¡(1/(2â€‹L),1Î¼â€‹Tâ€‹lnâ¡(f0â€‹Î¼2â€‹TLâ€‹Ïƒ2))ğœ‚12ğ¿1ğœ‡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“0superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘‡ğ¿superscriptğœ2\eta=\min\big{(}1/(2L),\frac{1}{\mu T}\ln(\frac{f_{0}\mu^{2}T}{L\sigma^{2}})\big{)} gives:

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(xT)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)]â©½eâˆ’Î¼2â€‹Lâ€‹Tâ€‹(fâ€‹(x0)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†))+Lâ€‹Ïƒ2Î¼2â€‹Tâ€‹lnâ¡(f0â€‹Î¼2â€‹TLâ€‹Ïƒ2).ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğ‘’ğœ‡2ğ¿ğ‘‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğ¿superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“0superscriptğœ‡2ğ‘‡ğ¿superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}\left[f(x^{T})-f(x^{\star})\right]\leqslant e^{-\frac{\mu}{2L}T}\big{(}f(x^{0})-f(x^{\star})\big{)}+\frac{L\sigma^{2}}{\mu^{2}T}\ln\big{(}\frac{f_{0}\mu^{2}T}{L\sigma^{2}}\big{)}\,.

Thus, for fixed target precision Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, using stepsize Î·Îµ=minâ¡(Î¼â€‹Îµ2â€‹Lâ€‹Ïƒ2,12â€‹L)subscriptğœ‚ğœ€ğœ‡ğœ€2ğ¿superscriptğœ212ğ¿\eta_{\varepsilon}=\min\left(\frac{\mu\varepsilon}{2L\sigma^{2}},\frac{1}{2L}\right) and setting TÎµ=âŒˆlnâ¡(Îµâˆ’1â€‹(fâ€‹(x0)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)))â€‹1Î·Îµâ€‹Î¼âŒ‰subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€superscriptğœ€1ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†1subscriptğœ‚ğœ€ğœ‡T_{\varepsilon}=\lceil\ln\big{(}\varepsilon^{-1}(f(x^{0})-f(x^{\star}))\big{)}\frac{1}{\eta_{\varepsilon}\mu}\rceil, we have:

fâ€‹(1TÎµâ€‹âˆ‘t<TÎµxt)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)â©½Îµ,ğ‘“1subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğœ€f\left(\frac{1}{T_{\varepsilon}}\sum_{t<T_{\varepsilon}}x^{t}\right)-f(x^{\star})\leqslant\varepsilon\,,

with a number of oracle calls

TÎµâ©½maxâ¡(2â€‹Lâ€‹Ïƒ2Îµâ€‹Î¼2,2â€‹LÎ¼)â€‹lnâ¡(Îµâˆ’1â€‹(fâ€‹(x0)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†))).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€2ğ¿superscriptğœ2ğœ€superscriptğœ‡22ğ¿ğœ‡superscriptğœ€1ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant\max\left(\frac{2L\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon\mu^{2}},\frac{2L}{\mu}\right)\ln\big{(}\varepsilon^{-1}(f(x^{0})-f(x^{\star}))\big{)}\,.
Proof.

For some tâ©¾0ğ‘¡0t\geqslant 0, denoting ft=ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(xt+1)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†f_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[f(x^{t+1})-f(x^{\star})\right], using relative smoothness, unbiasedness of the stochastic gradients and then relative strong convexity:

ft+1âˆ’ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡\displaystyle f_{t+1}-f_{t} â©½âˆ’Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt)â€–2]+Î·2â€‹L2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gtâ€–A2]absentğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2superscriptğœ‚2ğ¿2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ´2\displaystyle\leqslant-\eta\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|\nabla f(x^{t})\right\|}}^{2}\right]+\frac{\eta^{2}L}{2}\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}\right\|}}_{A}^{2}\right]
â©½âˆ’Î·â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt)â€–2]+Î·2â€‹Lâ€‹LA2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gtâ€–2]absentğœ‚ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2superscriptğœ‚2ğ¿subscriptğ¿ğ´2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\leqslant-\eta\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|\nabla f(x^{t})\right\|}}^{2}\right]+\frac{\eta^{2}LL_{A}}{2}\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}\right\|}}^{2}\right]
â©½âˆ’Î·â€‹(1âˆ’Î·â€‹Lâ€‹LA2)â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt)â€–2]+Î·2â€‹Lâ€‹LAâ€‹Ïƒ22.absentğœ‚1ğœ‚ğ¿subscriptğ¿ğ´2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2superscriptğœ‚2ğ¿subscriptğ¿ğ´superscriptğœ22\displaystyle\leqslant-\eta\left(1-\frac{\eta LL_{A}}{2}\right)\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|\nabla f(x^{t})\right\|}}^{2}\right]+\frac{\eta^{2}LL_{A}\sigma^{2}}{2}\,.

Using relative strong convexity of fğ‘“f, we have:

â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt)â€–2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2\displaystyle{{\left\|\nabla f(x^{t})\right\|}}^{2} â©¾1LAâ€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt)â€–A2absent1subscriptğ¿ğ´superscriptsubscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ´2\displaystyle\geqslant\frac{1}{L_{A}}{{\left\|\nabla f(x^{t})\right\|}}_{A}^{2}
â©½2â€‹Î¼LAâ€‹ft,absent2ğœ‡subscriptğ¿ğ´subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡\displaystyle\leqslant\frac{2\mu}{L_{A}}f_{t}\,,

yielding, for Î·<1/(Lâ€‹LA)ğœ‚1ğ¿subscriptğ¿ğ´\eta<1/(LL_{A})

ft+1âˆ’ftâ©½âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹Î¼LAâ€‹ft+Î·2â€‹Lâ€‹LAâ€‹Ïƒ22.subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡2ğœ‚ğœ‡subscriptğ¿ğ´subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡superscriptğœ‚2ğ¿subscriptğ¿ğ´superscriptğœ22f_{t+1}-f_{t}\leqslant-2\eta\frac{\mu}{L_{A}}f_{t}+\frac{\eta^{2}LL_{A}\sigma^{2}}{2}\,.

Then, for some T>0ğ‘‡0T>0 and since LAâ©½1subscriptğ¿ğ´1L_{A}\leqslant 1, sum the above inequality multiplied by (1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼)âˆ’tâˆ’1superscript1ğœ‚ğœ‡ğ‘¡1\left(1-\eta\mu\right)^{-t-1}:

âˆ‘0â©½tâ©½Tâˆ’1(1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼)âˆ’tâˆ’1â€‹ft+1âˆ’(1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼)âˆ’tâ€‹ftsubscript0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡1superscript1ğœ‚ğœ‡ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡1superscript1ğœ‚ğœ‡ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡\displaystyle\sum_{0\leqslant t\leqslant T-1}\left(1-\eta\mu\right)^{-t-1}f_{t+1}-\left(1-\eta\mu\right)^{-t}f_{t} â©½Î·2â€‹Lâ€‹Ïƒ22â€‹âˆ‘0â©½tâ©½Tâˆ’1(1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼)âˆ’tâˆ’1absentsuperscriptğœ‚2ğ¿superscriptğœ22subscript0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡1superscript1ğœ‚ğœ‡ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\leqslant\frac{\eta^{2}L\sigma^{2}}{2}\sum_{0\leqslant t\leqslant T-1}\left(1-\eta\mu\right)^{-t-1}
â©½Î·2â€‹Lâ€‹Ïƒ22â€‹(1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼)âˆ’tâˆ’1Î·â€‹Î¼,absentsuperscriptğœ‚2ğ¿superscriptğœ22superscript1ğœ‚ğœ‡ğ‘¡1ğœ‚ğœ‡\displaystyle\leqslant\frac{\eta^{2}L\sigma^{2}}{2}\frac{\left(1-\eta\mu\right)^{-t-1}}{\eta\mu}\,,

leading to the desired result. âˆ

F.2. SGD under smoothness and convexity assumptions

Lemma 5 (SGD, convex and smooth).

Let f:ğ’³â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’ğ’³â„f:\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R} convex and Lğ¿L-smooth. Let (ft,gt)tâ©¾0subscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(f_{t},g_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be first order oracle calls such that for all tâ©¾0ğ‘¡0t\geqslant 0:

âˆ€xâˆˆğ’³,{ğ”¼â€‹[ftâ€‹(x)]=fâ€‹(x),ğ”¼â€‹[gtâ€‹(x)]=âˆ‡fâ€‹(x),ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gtâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(x)â€–2]â©½Ïƒ2,\forall x\in\mathcal{X}\,,\quad\left\{\begin{aligned} &\mathbb{E}\left[f_{t}(x)\right]=f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[g_{t}(x)\right]=\nabla f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}(x)-\nabla f(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant\sigma^{2}\,,\end{aligned}\right.

for some Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0. Let (xt)tâ©¾0subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(x_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be generated with:

âˆ€tâ©¾0,xt+1=xtâˆ’Î·â€‹gtâ€‹(xt),formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¡0superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\forall t\geqslant 0\,,\quad x^{t+1}=x^{t}-\eta g_{t}(x^{t})\,,

for a fixed stepsize 12â€‹Lâ©¾Î·>012ğ¿ğœ‚0\frac{1}{2L}\geqslant\eta>0, and assume that all the iterates lie in ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}. Assume that fğ‘“f is minimized over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} at some interior point xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star}. Denote, for T>0ğ‘‡0T>0, xÂ¯T=1Tâ€‹âˆ‘0â©½t<TxtsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡1ğ‘‡subscript0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\bar{x}^{T}=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{0\leqslant t<T}x^{t}. We have for any T>0ğ‘‡0T>0:

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(xÂ¯T)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)]â©½â€–x0âˆ’xâ‹†â€–2Î·â€‹T+Î·â€‹Ïƒ2.ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2ğœ‚ğ‘‡ğœ‚superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}\left[f(\bar{x}^{T})-f(x^{\star})\right]\leqslant\frac{{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}}{\eta T}+\eta\sigma^{2}\,.

For fixed T>0ğ‘‡0T>0, setting Î·=min(1/(2L)),â€–x0âˆ’xâ‹†â€–Ïƒâ€‹T)\eta=\min\Big{(}1/(2L)),\frac{{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}}{\sigma\sqrt{T}}\Big{)} gives:

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(xT)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)]â©½2â€‹â€–x0âˆ’xâ‹†â€–â€‹ÏƒT+2â€‹Lâ€‹â€–x0âˆ’xâ‹†â€–2T.ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2normsuperscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğœğ‘‡2ğ¿superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2ğ‘‡\mathbb{E}\left[f(x^{T})-f(x^{\star})\right]\leqslant\frac{2{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}\sigma}{\sqrt{T}}+\frac{2L{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}}{T}\,.

Thus, for fixed target precision Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, we have:

fâ€‹(1TÎµâ€‹âˆ‘t<TÎµxt)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)â©½Îµ,ğ‘“1subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğœ€f\left(\frac{1}{T_{\varepsilon}}\sum_{t<T_{\varepsilon}}x^{t}\right)-f(x^{\star})\leqslant\varepsilon\,,

with a number of oracle calls

TÎµâ©½4â€‹â€–x0âˆ’xâ‹†â€–2â€‹(4â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹Îµâˆ’2+Lâ€‹Îµâˆ’1).subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€4superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥â‹†24superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2ğ¿superscriptğœ€1T_{\varepsilon}\leqslant 4{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}\big{(}4\sigma^{2}\varepsilon^{-2}+L\varepsilon^{-1}\big{)}\,.
Proof.

Denote et=ğ”¼â€‹[â€–xtâˆ’xâ‹†â€–2]subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2e_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|x^{t}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}\right]. We have:

et+1âˆ’etsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡\displaystyle e_{t+1}-e_{t} â©½âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹âŸ¨âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt),xtâˆ’xâ‹†âŸ©+Î·2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gt2â€–]absent2ğœ‚âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼delimited-[]normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\leqslant-2\eta\langle\nabla f(x^{t}),x^{t}-x^{\star}\rangle+\eta^{2}\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}^{2}\right\|}}\right]
â©½âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹ft+Î·2â€‹(ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(xt)â€–2]+Ïƒ2)absent2ğœ‚subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡superscriptğœ‚2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leqslant-2\eta f_{t}+\eta^{2}(\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|\nabla f(x^{t})\right\|}}^{2}\right]+\sigma^{2})
â©½âˆ’2â€‹Î·â€‹(1âˆ’Lâ€‹Î·)â€‹ft+Î·2â€‹Ïƒ2absent2ğœ‚1ğ¿ğœ‚subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leqslant-2\eta(1-L\eta)f_{t}+\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}
â©½âˆ’Î·â€‹ft+Î·2â€‹Ïƒ2,absentğœ‚subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leqslant-\eta f_{t}+\eta^{2}\sigma^{2}\,,

where we used convexity and smoothness assumptions. Then, summing:

âˆ‘t<Tftâ©½e0âˆ’eTÎ·+Tâ€‹Î·â€‹Ïƒ2,subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘’0subscriptğ‘’ğ‘‡ğœ‚ğ‘‡ğœ‚superscriptğœ2\sum_{t<T}f_{t}\leqslant\frac{e_{0}-e_{T}}{\eta}+T\eta\sigma^{2}\,,

leading to the desired result. âˆ

F.3. SGD under convex assumptions

Lemma 6 (SGD, convex).

Let f:ğ’³â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’ğ’³â„f:\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R} convex. Let (ft,gt)tâ©¾0subscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(f_{t},g_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be first order oracle calls such that for all tâ©¾0ğ‘¡0t\geqslant 0:

âˆ€xâˆˆğ’³,{ğ”¼â€‹[ftâ€‹(x)]=fâ€‹(x),ğ”¼â€‹[gtâ€‹(x)]âˆˆâˆ‚fâ€‹(x),ğ”¼â€‹[â€–gtâ€‹(x)â€–2]â©½B2,\forall x\in\mathcal{X}\,,\quad\left\{\begin{aligned} &\mathbb{E}\left[f_{t}(x)\right]=f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[g_{t}(x)\right]\in\partial f(x)\,,\\ &\mathbb{E}\left[{{\left\|g_{t}(x)\right\|}}^{2}\right]\leqslant B^{2}\,,\end{aligned}\right.

for some B>0ğµ0B>0. For pğ’³subscriptğ‘ğ’³p_{\mathcal{X}} the projection on the convex set ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}, let (xt)tâ©¾0subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0(x_{t})_{t\geqslant 0} be generated with:

âˆ€tâ©¾0,xt+1=pğ’³â€‹(xtâˆ’Î·â€‹gtâ€‹(xt)),formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¡0superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘ğ’³superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\forall t\geqslant 0\,,\quad x^{t+1}=p_{\mathcal{X}}\left(x^{t}-\eta g_{t}(x^{t})\right)\,,

for a fixed stepsize Î·>0ğœ‚0\eta>0. Assume that fğ‘“f is minimized over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} at some interior point xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star}. We have for any T>0ğ‘‡0T>0 and for Î·=2â€‹D2B2â€‹Tğœ‚2superscriptğ·2superscriptğµ2ğ‘‡\eta=\sqrt{\frac{2D^{2}}{B^{2}T}} for D2â©¾â€–x0âˆ’xâ‹†â€–2superscriptğ·2superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2D^{2}\geqslant{{\left\|x^{0}-x^{\star}\right\|}}^{2}:

fâ€‹(1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t<Txt)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)â©½2Tâ€‹Bâ€‹D.ğ‘“1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2ğ‘‡ğµğ·f\left(\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t<T}x^{t}\right)-f(x^{\star})\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2}{T}}BD\,.

Thus, for fixed target precision Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, setting TÎµ=âŒˆ2â€‹Îµâˆ’2â€‹B2â€‹D2âŒ‰subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€2superscriptğœ€2superscriptğµ2superscriptğ·2T_{\varepsilon}=\lceil 2\varepsilon^{-2}B^{2}D^{2}\rceil and using stepsize Î·Îµ=2â€‹ÎµB2subscriptğœ‚ğœ€2ğœ€superscriptğµ2\eta_{\varepsilon}=\frac{\sqrt{2}\varepsilon}{B^{2}}, we have:

fâ€‹(1TÎµâ€‹âˆ‘t<TÎµxt)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)â©½Îµ.ğ‘“1subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğœ€superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğœ€f\left(\frac{1}{T_{\varepsilon}}\sum_{t<T_{\varepsilon}}x^{t}\right)-f(x^{\star})\leqslant\varepsilon\,.
Proof.

For any yâˆˆğ’³ğ‘¦ğ’³y\in\mathcal{X}, using properties of pğ’³subscriptğ‘ğ’³p_{\mathcal{X}}:

â€–xt+1âˆ’yâ€–2superscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1ğ‘¦2\displaystyle{{\left\|x^{t+1}-y\right\|}}^{2} =â€–pğ’³â€‹(xtâˆ’Î·â€‹gtâ€‹(xt))âˆ’yâ€–2absentsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ‘ğ’³superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¦2\displaystyle={{\left\|p_{\mathcal{X}}\left(x^{t}-\eta g_{t}(x^{t})\right)-y\right\|}}^{2}
â©½â€–xtâˆ’Î·â€‹gtâ€‹(xt)âˆ’yâ€–2absentsuperscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¦2\displaystyle\leqslant{{\left\|x^{t}-\eta g_{t}(x^{t})-y\right\|}}^{2}
